characters: OUT HERE IN THE MIDDLE OF THE NIGHT
WHAT THE HELL ARE YOU TWO DOING

dialogues.speaker: YA-HOOOO
dialogues.text: Wearing goggles and helmets, two old men SCREAM like craz kids as their SPUTTERING biplane loops and rolls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SHERIFF'S DEPUTY naps inside his police cruiser. Suddenly, his radar WAILS: it flashes "120". ROAR! The biplane BLASTS past, upside down, the old men HOLLER and wave. The cop SCREECHES off after the biplane lights and SIREN BLAZING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Upside down, the old men CACKLE as the police cruiser quickly, impotently falls away below.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The plane flies away, barely under control: it careens and SPUTTERS off into a huge heroic sunset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A phone RINGS. A hand sketches: a whimsical lion peers out of a cornfield. The ARTIST picks up the phone: ARTIST (into phone) Hello?

dialogues.speaker: TELEPHONE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Walter Caldwell...? I have bad news. It's about your two uncles...

dialogues.speaker: DAY 6
dialogues.text: He drives past a lonely landscape. A distant voice ECHOES

dialogues.speaker: MAE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Walter...? Walter...?!  WHITE Revision - 8/25/02

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: MATCH DISSOLVE: a boy, WALTER stares out at the same landscape. He is pale, quiet: one of life's wallflowers. The clothes, the car, the road signs, the RADIO MUSIC... all say the time is now the early 1960's. His mother, MAE, drives; she is far deeper into her desperate thirties than she will ever admit.

dialogues.speaker: MAE
dialogues.text: Walter! Good news! You're spending the summer with your two uncles.... Walter CHOKES, lunges for the window and hangs out it THROWING-UP. Mae scowls, fires up a long cigarette. MAE (Cont'd) It'll only be a few weeks, a month or two, tops. I'll definitely come get you before school starts. Walter turns from the window and sits, pale.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: That's what you said at that summer camp. And the time with the nuns. And before that...

dialogues.speaker: MAE
dialogues.text: Walter! Look! I promise this time. Scout's honor. OK...? Cross-my-heart-hope-to-die! OK? Walter still isn't buying it. Mae SIGHS. MAE (Cont'd) Walter: someday you're gonna have to learn to trust people. Or you'll grow up bitter and disappointed. He looks bitter and disappointed right now.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Where you going this time?

dialogues.speaker: MAE
dialogues.text: "The Fort Worth College of Court Reporting". I met a guy last night, he's pulling some strings. Court Reporters have their pick of good jobs, and their pick of good husband material: lawyers, judges, cops... Walter thinks; DISSOLVE TO:  WHITE Revision - 8/25/02

dialogues.speaker: WALTER'S IMAGINATION
dialogues.text: Dreamlike, a quick jump into Walter's head: in an imagine courtroom, Mae busily court-reports, avoiding the admirin smiles of respectable LAWYERS, COPS, THE JUDGE... ...and returns the lewd grin of a slimy CONVICT in chains

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Walter SIGHS, glumly looks back out the window.

dialogues.speaker: MAE
dialogues.text: You'll have fun with your uncles. You'll see.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Mom. You're an only child. (off her look: ) I know what uncles are. Mae colors slightly, exhales hard, a blast of smoke.

dialogues.speaker: MAE
dialogues.text: Well Mr. Smarty-pants, they really are your uncles: your great uncles my mother's brothers. They disap- peared forty years ago and just now showed up back here in Texas.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Can't I come with you?

dialogues.speaker: MAE
dialogues.text: No! I'm gonna be working my little tail off learning Court Reporting! I'm doing everything I can to keep this family together, Walter. How about some help here?! OK? He nods, retreats back into his silence. MAE (Cont'd) Now look. They say these two old men got millions stashed away, in cash. They got no kids, nobody to leave all that money to. And me and you, why, we're as close as any family they got...

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: You want them to like me so they'll die and leave us their money? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 9 10 WHITE Revision - 8/25/02 4.

dialogues.speaker: MAE
dialogues.text: We could settle down, maybe buy a house: wouldn't that be nice...? (Walter looks wistful) But watch out for other relatives. You wouldn't believe all the crooks, backstabbers and thieves we have in this family...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter nods soberly. Mae turns the Cadillac onto a dirt road; it's flanked by a huge terrifying sign: "NO TRESPASSING! Violators will DISAPPEAR!" Walter GASPS. MAE (Cont'd) This is it! Oh, look at your face. She TSK-TSKS, SPITS in a Kleenex, rubs it over his face, as his big eyes follow more alarming signs: "DANGER!

dialogues.speaker: EXPLOSIVES
dialogues.text: MAE (Cont'd) By the way: I hear these two were in some state nuthouse for forty years, and got all their money from a big lawsuit or something... Walter GULPS. More signs: "LOOSE RABID ATTACK DOGS!"

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Maybe we should'a called first....

dialogues.speaker: MAE
dialogues.text: Naa! Older people just love surprises.... Here we are! The Cadillac pulls up; Walter looks out, GULPS:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A ramshackle home: a tower leans crookedly. Beyond, a wide, blue lake fades into the horizon. Motley chickens loiter around an old barn. An old truck rusts silently. Dogs HOWL: a pack of ugly stray dogs races up and SLAMS into the car, HOWLING, WAILING, teeth SNAPPING.

dialogues.speaker: MAE
dialogues.text: Show them you're friendly. Let them smell your hand. Walter thinks not. The dogs are joined by a large SQUEALING hog, another member of the dog pack. Then GUNSHOTS: the dogs race off. More GUNSHOTS and YELLS. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHITE Revision - 8/25/02 5. 10 11

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: MAE (Cont'd) Sounds like they're down by that lake. Come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In shallow water, a catfish swims. The water EXPLODES. Standing out in the lake, wearing big hip-waders, HUB and GARTH fire shotguns down into the water. KA-BOOM!

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: Where'd it go?

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: There! Between your feet!

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: Ha! Winged him!

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: He's running for it! Both BLAST AWAY at the frantic fish: BAM-BAM-BAM! CLICK GARTH (Cont'd) Damn! Empty!

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: You get ammo! I'll cover him!

dialogues.speaker: MAE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Yoo hoo! Startled, both look up: at the shoreline, Mae waves.

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: (to Garth, disgusted) You sent for a hooker?

dialogues.speaker: MAE
dialogues.text: Uncle Hub! Uncle Garth! It's me! Mae! Your niece! Pearl's daughter And I brought Walter! Your nephew! Behind her, Walter peers out timidly. The two men CURSE:

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: Relatives!

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: Damn it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 12 13 BLUE Revision - 11/3/02 6.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wet angry men storm up, pursued by the wheedling Mae.

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: We're old, dammit! Leave us alone

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: Last thing we need is some little Sissy-boy hanging around all summer The furious men storm inside. Mae smiles at her son.

dialogues.speaker: MAE
dialogues.text: Walter honey? Why don't you stay out here and play. She goes in; Walter sits, hears the ARGUMENT CONTINUE: MAE (0.S.) (Cont'd) He can help out here! Do chores!

dialogues.speaker: HUB, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Help out? Look at him: the kid's a damn weenie!

dialogues.speaker: MAE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: That's why he needs to be around real men! Like you two! Walter SIGHS. A shadow covers him: the pig glares right in Walter's face, eyeball to eyeball, almost... hungrily.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Good boy. Nice doggie! Go play. The pig GROWLS, a pretty-fair dog imitation. WALTER (Cont'd) Mom. ..?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mae STARTS THE ENGINE. Beside the car, Walter stands miserable, shoulders slumped, a shoddy bag at his feet.

dialogues.speaker: MAE
dialogues.text: This is for your own good, Walter... You know, I bet all that money's hidden real close-by. Imagine! Real buried treasure, like in those books you're always reading! Walter's misery remains impregnable. Mae gives up. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BLUE Revision - 11/3/02 7. 13 14

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: MAE (Cont'd) Walter: maybe if you'd smile once in a while, then people might like you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sees two hostile uncles staring, arms crossed, furious MAE (Cont'd) Now. Give me a big smile to remember you by. Walter tries: it's more of a grimace than a grin. MAE (Cont'd) You're gonna have to work on that smile while I'm gone. OK? Walter nods solemnly. Mae blows a kiss and motors off. Morose, Walter watches the dogs chase the Cadillac away. Walter picks up his bag, turns, looks up at the brothers: OK, now what? Finally:

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: Well. Supper time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter watches the uncles wolf down fish, steak, sausage. The dogs and the pig crowd to look in a porch window. Walter stares down at huge portions of shot-up fish, stea and sausage. He tries the fish, bites something hard, SPITS a shotgun pellet out onto his plate: PLINK. SIGH. He hacks off a chunk of steak, chews with all his strengt

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: This steak is... weird.

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: Venison! Not steak! Walter frowns, decides to try the sausage: not bad. HUB (Cont'd) Pork!

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: We raise our own pigs. Walter freezes mid-bite, looks at the window: now the pig glares even more murderously at him, and GROWLS. Then, Hub suddenly SLAMS his fist down on the table. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 14 15 BLUE Revision - 11/3/02 8.

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: Know what I hate about houseguests? This! Dinner table chit-chat! Acting so damn nice and polite!

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: Hell Hub! Then just be yourself! Hub glares at Walter: well? Walter GULPS, nods, agrees. Dinner resumes, in SILENCE. Walter eats and tries to ignore the pig's now-murderous stare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The uncles sit, sipping huge glasses of what may be iced tea; beside them, two shotguns stand ready, close at hand Sitting on the porch steps, Walter wonders: they seem to be waiting for something... Finally, he SIGHS.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: If my mom calls, can we hear the phone out here?

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: Don't have one.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: No telephone? Walter thinks about that. WALTER (Cont'd) OK if I watch television?

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: Ain't got one.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: No television? What do you do? Dizzy, Walter wonders if he's fallen off the edge of the planet. GRAVEL CRUNCHES: a car approaches. Both men lean forward, PUMP their shotguns. Below, a SMILING SALESMAN alights from his car.

dialogues.speaker: SALESMAN
dialogues.text: Gentlemen! Word is out you two are sophisticated men of means. Do you worry about the future? Of course you do! That's why I, a representative of the Mississippi Mutual Insurance Company... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 15 16 BLUE Revision - 11/3/02 9.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: BLAM-BLAM! Hub and Garth fire BLASTS just over the salesman's head. Walter YELPS, ducks. The Salesman SHRIEKS, jumps in his car, SCREECHES off. The dogs HOWL and chase the car away. Walter shivers, stunned; he stares as the brothers calmly sit back down, drink, and reload.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: There's plenty of entertainment on TV. Educational stuff too! It's a good thing to do in the evenings! GRAVEL CRUNCHES again. The brothers raise their shotguns. A GRINNING SALESMAN appears:

dialogues.speaker: GRINNING SALESMAN
dialogues.text: Rumor has it you two got millions stashed away! Why not put that money to work for you with the high return only investing in gold and silver can bring.... BLAM-BLAM-BLAM! Another salesman flees for his life. The brothers sip reflectively, and reload.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Everybody loves TV! You oughta get one! You'd like it! Really! The brothers consider that. Gravel CRUNCHES: A BEAMING SALESMAN opens his trunk: a display of kitchen gadgets. BLAM! BLAM! BLAM! The salesman hightails it away. Finally, Hub turns to Walter, and says definitively:

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: No TV. The brothers sit back reflectively.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: Nice evening... Peaceful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter gingerly cradles a lit lantern and his bag; he stares up at narrow, steep stairs, winding up out of sigh

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: You sleep up there... the tower It sounds so ominous. Walter GULPS, nods, inches upstairs (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHITE Revision - 8/25/02 10. 16 17 18 19

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: GARTH (Cont'd) Hey! We don't know nothing about kids. If you need something....

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: Find it yourself! Better yet learn to do without!

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: We're both gettin' old...

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: ...and fixin' to die any minute! If we kick off in the middle of the night, you're on your own. Eyes huge, Walter stares at them, his imagination whirls:

dialogues.speaker: WALTER'S IMAGINATION
dialogues.text: In his p.j.s, Walter comes in for breakfast, YAWNS, calml sits at the table beside two clothed skeletons, the forme Hub and Garth. Walter nonchalantly MUNCHES his Cheerios.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Walter flinches, nods; he continues up the steep steps.

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: Jumpy little feller.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: Mmmm. Quiet though....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter staggers in, looks around... the tower room is heaped with debris, trunks, chests, suitcases, junk. He opens his bag, takes out a toothbrush, sees a small door by the stairs: a bathroom? He opens the door something tumbles over him: an old Santa Claus costume. He tries on the beard, admires his reflection in a murky mirror. Then, he hears: downstairs, two snoring-world- champions WARBLE and hit every SNORING-note Man can hear. He SIGHS, BRUSHES his teeth, further explores the room: One trunk is covered with exotic travel stickers. He fingers the big padlock. Locked. Walter looks crushed. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHITE Revision - 8/25/02 11. 19 20 21

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He crawls into bed; as he leans out to blow out the candl he grabs a big knob on the headboard... the knob comes off in his hand, he tumbles onto the floor Walter stares at the knob in his hand: a key falls out. Walter looks at the key, then at the locked trunk. He tries the key in the lock. CLICK: it fits. Slowly, he opens the lid: CREAK... empty. No money, no jewels, only:

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Sand...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Puzzled, he runs his fingers through sand that covers the trunk bottom. Enchanted, he SNIFFS a handful: it smells exotic. MUSIC ECHOES, evocative, Arabic perhaps. Beneath the sand he sees something, picks it up: it's a faded photo of the most beautiful woman he's ever seen; dark hair, olive skin, piercing eyes. Walter wonders. BANG! A door SLAMS. Walter leaps to the window, looks out: below, Hub strides purposefully out of the house carrying a toilet plunger; he disappears into darkness. Walter runs out of the room, leaps down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter bursts out the front door, runs after Hub.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter arrives at the lake, looks around: no one there. It's spooky. A NOISE: startled, Walter turns... Hub looms over him, the toilet plunger raised in attack.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Aaaagh! Walter cowers. But Hub stumbles on past, down towards the water. Walter stares: Hub now stands at the shore, waiting; silently, the dogs and pig all join walter. WALTER (Cont'd) He's sleep-walking! The dogs lay down, eyes fixed on Hub. Watching. Waiting. Hub smiles, a cold smile. Then, with a CRY, he swings his plunger like a sword and begins to fight: parry, thrust, savage overhead cut... Walter watches, eyes wide; from far away, he hears echoes of SWORDS CLANGING, HOOFBEATS, WHINNIES, CRIES OF MEN IN BATTLE. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHITE Revision - 8/25/02 12. 21 22 23 24

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Walter and the animals watch the thrilling moonlit battle at the water's edge. MATCH DISSOLVE TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning. Walter, the dogs, and the pig all sleep curled up together. Walter stirs, sits up, looks around: The lakeshore is deserted, Hub is gone. Walter wonders: was it all a dream? A rooster CROWS. Frantic, he runs toward the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter skulks up, looks in: at the table, Garth works on huge stacks of mail. Garth stands, walks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter sneaks in, starts for the stairs... but the stacks of mail are too intriguing. He thumbs through the mail: It's all coupon responses from magazines and mail order catalogs; all have "Please have a salesman call" checked or written in. Walter GASPS, shocked. FOOTSTEPS APPROACH. Walter panics, tries to look innocent, as Garth enters.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: Thought you'd run away. Walter shakes his head "no". Garth hurriedly gathers up the mail, puts it away. Then, Garth CRACKS eggs into a huge frying pan full of SIZZLING sausage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter sits, confused. Finally, he just has to ask:

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Y-y-you send mail to all those salesmen? You ask them to come here so you can shoot at them?

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: (sighs, finally nods) Don't tell Hub. It'd take all the fun out, ruin it for him. Walter looks even more confused. Garth stirs the eggs. GARTH (Cont'd) Every man needs a hobby. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHITE Revision - 8/25/02 13. 24

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Walter considers that. Hub enters, rubbing his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: Brand new mattress. And I'm still waking up tired and sore. Garth smiles knowingly, then sees Walter staring at Hub. Garth wonders, dishes out eggs and sausage. Walter eats, then freezes, he's being watched: in the window, the pig now has an angry rooster perched on its head; now two animals glare murderously at him. SIGH.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: So... you two disappeared for forty whole years? Where were you? The brothers chew reflectively. Finally....

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: Africa, mostly.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Africa? Where in Africa?

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: North Africa. Morocco, Algeria, Kenya, the Sudan....

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: ...but that was long ago, and we're old and worthless now! All eat. Silence. Walter tries again.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Still, I bet you two sure got lotsa good stories to tell, huh...?

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: Stories! Ain't nothing sadder than a couple'a has-beens jabbering about the "good old days". Those days are through, and so are we! All eat in silence. Long pause.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: I don't know how a feller can concentrate on eating with all this talk-talk-talk. For just a second, Walter thinks he sees a twinkle in Garth's eye. Then, it's gone.  WHITE Revision - 8/25/02 14.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The uncles and the boy hack at hard Texas earth, the star of an ambitious garden. Walter struggles with a too-large hoe. The dogs and pig watch, puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: I_ hate this!

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: We're retired. Gardening is what retired people do.

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: Why the hell do we want any damn vegetables, anyway?

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: They're good for you. Make you live to be a hundred.

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: To hell with that! He throws down his hoe, storms off.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: Getting old's bad enough! Getting pissed-off about it don't help! Walter absorbs this. A horn HONKS: a car drives up, acros the new garden rows: loud relatives pile out, all talking at once: RALPH; HELEN; MARTHA, 13; and TWO WILD BOYS, 9. ALL (all talk) Uncle Garth! Where's Uncle Hub? Kids, say hello to Uncle Garth!

dialogues.speaker: CHILDREN
dialogues.text: Hello Uncle Garth! ADULTS (all talk) We're here for a nice long visit, the whole weekend! We know how lonely our favorite uncles get! Garth CURSES, throws down his hoe, STORMS off. The loving smiles instantly disappear: all turn and glare at walter.

dialogues.speaker: RALPH
dialogues.text: Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: W-W-Walter. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHITE Revision - 8/25/02 15.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Walter, Walter... Mae's boy? Walter nods. The others look confused. Helen explains: HELEN (Cont'd) Pearl's daughter. That loose widow- woman, always "running around".

dialogues.speaker: RALPH
dialogues.text: Figures she'd try to muscle in.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Is Mae here? (Walter shakes his head) How long are you here for? (he shrugs, who knows?) Well! We'll just see about that! She storms off. SCREECH! The kids fly in all directions. The dogpack YELPS, scatters. Ralph glares at Walter

dialogues.speaker: RALPH
dialogues.text: We know what you're up to. And you're not getting away with it. He stalks off. Walter thinks. Then he throws down his hoe and walks toward the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter reaches the door, starts to go in, but hears:

dialogues.speaker: HELEN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Men at your age! Taking in that strange little boy! He's probably robbing you blind! Inside, Walter sees Hub and Helen ARGUING, toe to toe. HELEN (Cont'd) If you want young people around you're welcome to any of mine! They're very well behaved! Walter hears a SQUEAL behind him, turns: the two wild boys ride the terrorized pig, BAWLING Indian war-whoops. Walter rolls his eyes, looks back inside:

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: Hell! We don't want any damn kids! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHITE Revision - 8/25/02 16. 27 28 29

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: You two can't even take care of yourselves! Now you take in this strange boy with all his problems?!

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: His momma's due back before long.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: That woman? Ha! What I hear, she may never come back! What then? You'll be stuck with him!

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Walter, miserable, backs away. He slinks off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martha sits reading, sees Walter staring at her. She raises a haughty eyebrow: "Well?" On the spot, he BABBLES

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: I read a lot of books too.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Oooh. I'm so impressed. He peers at her book: "Horses". He starts to speak... MARTHA (Cont'd) Yes: horses. Daddy says when my uncles die I can have a pony. Walter blinks, scrambles to think of another opener.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Uncle Hub and Uncle Garth told how they used to live in Africa.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: They're big fat liars. That's what Daddy says. He should know. He's a lawyer.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: But, but...! Then where were they for forty years? Where'd they get all their money?

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: They robbed banks. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHITE Revision - 8/25/02 17. 29 30 31

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Walter GASPS. Martha is quite matter-of-fact. MARTHA (Cont'd) Daddy has it all figured out. Years ago, there were these two famous bank robbers nobody ever caught. They wore disguises... (Walter looks dizzy) The famous Santa Claus Bandits. Walter GASPS, shaken. Dazed, he slowly goes inside.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Take him to the county boy's home! They know how to handle troublemakers like him!

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: If his momma doesn't show back up soon, we may have to...

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: If we're lucky, we won't live that long! Walter slinks in. Hub and Helen stand toe-to-toe.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: I'm telling you: take him to the orphanage right this minute!

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: Whether we take him to the orphanage or tie him up and throw him in the lake, it's our business, not yours! Walter GASPS: all turn, see him standing there, wide-eyed

dialogues.speaker: RALPH
dialogues.text: Here he is now! Spying! Ralph roughly grabs Walter: Walter panics, kicks out and SMACKS Ralph's knee hard; Ralph YELPS, Walter bolts away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter races out the front door and down the driveway; he streaks toward the road, running away as fast as he can.  BLUE Revision - 11/3/02 18.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A RECEPTIONIST puts on her hat and coat to leave; but one last CALL COMES IN. She SIGHS, answers.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: Fort Worth College of Court Reporting....

dialogues.speaker: WALTER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I need to find my mom! She's a student there!

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, we're closed...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter: exhausted, face streaked with dirt and tears. She SIGHS,

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: It's an emergency! Please! Her name's Mae! Mae Coleman! scans a card file. INTERCUT PHONE CONVERSATION.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: Hmmm. I'm sorry, there's no Mae Coleman registered here.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Oh, well, try Mae Carter....

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: Uh... no, I'm sorry...

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: How about Mabel Cartwright? Mame Callaway? Donna Tomko?

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: Young man, are you in some kind of trouble?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: She's gotta be there! She just started.... She takes a deep breath, and replies delicately:

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: Our classes all started back in January. No one could possibly have just started.... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Walter GASPS, turns white, the wind knocked out of him. RECEPTIONIST (Cont'd) Hello? Hello? Young man! Where are you...? Walter panics, hangs up. As darkness falls, a small figur sits on the gas station's low front step and buries his head in his knees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A new 1962 Buick pulls up to a stop sign with three unhap men inside, out looking for Walter. Hub GRINDS the gears.

dialogues.speaker: RALPH
dialogues.text: Ouch! Hub! I don't know why you have to drive, it's my car....

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: Stop whining! Hub GRINDS the gears again. Ralph glowers.

dialogues.speaker: RALPH
dialogues.text: When we find him, that kid's gonna get a piece of my mind! Down a ways, Garth sees the gas station... and Walter.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: There he is....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter studies a piece of paper. The Buick pulls in, runs over the air hose: DING-DING. Walter looks up, goes back to studying his paper

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Garth and Ralph start to get out.

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: Lawyer. Stay in the car. Ralph starts to argue, sees Hub's glare, sits back down. Hub nods "go ahead" to Garth, settles back to wait.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: Hub. Come on. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHITE Revision - 8/25/02 20. 36 37

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: What? Me? You go.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: Hub. Get out of the car. Hub CURSES, follows Garth over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter studies his paper. Garth sits on the curb beside Walter, motions for Hub to sit. Hub scowls, but sits. They look at Walter's paper, a page ripped from a phone book: it's the area code map of the United States.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: Planning your next move? Walter nods. Studies his map. GARTH (Cont'd) Where you figure on going?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Here. Area code 406... Montana.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: Why Montana?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Their license plates say "Big Sky Country". Hub and Garth nod. It's a good choice. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: Family...!

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: hat Hub means is: sometimes, family an be a real pain in the butt. os Walter's lower-lip quivers, he hides his face in his knee The two brothers look awkward. GARTH (Cont'd) How come you aren't heading to Ft. Worth, where your momma is?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: She's not there. She lied. Again Hub and Garth exchange troubled looks: uh oh. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHITE Revision - 8/25/02 21.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: You got a father somewhere?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Mom says he died. World War Two. Hub and Garth exchange "wait a minute" looks.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: Kid. That war was over twenty years ago!

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Yeah, she's not good with numbers. He probably just took off before I was old enough to remember.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: Look kid. We know you got your heart set on Montana, but it's late... Hub, help me out here.

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: Why? Sounds like his mind's made up. Good luck in Montana, kid! Hub stands to go; Garth yanks him back down.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: We got better maps than that one, back at the house. Right Hub?

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: A man needs a good map, that's for sure.... All nod: all agree on the importance of good maps.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: I've been in the orphan home before. I don't wanna go back

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: Dammit kid! It ain't our fault you got a lousy damn mother! Hub is puzzled why Garth now glares furiously at him. HUB (Cont'd) What?! Walter stands. Consults his map, orients himself. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHITE Revision - 8/25/02 22. 37 38

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: I should get going. Which way is north? Hub points. Garth shoves Hub's hand down, glares at him. Ralph angrily HONKS his horn. Hub notes it:

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: I'll say one thing for this kid: he sure pisses off the relatives. That gives Garth an idea, an inspired idea:

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: Look kid: do us a favor! If you come back to the house and stay awhile, why, our relatives will hate it! In fact, I bet they'll hate it so much they'll go away and leave us all the hell alone!

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: It's so crazy, it just might work!

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: So kid. C'mon! Help us out here! Walter hesitates. Hub frowns at his watch.

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: Make up your mind! We got salesmen back home, waitin' on us!

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Oh. Guess I could come back, for awhile. Seeing it's so important... All stand and nod agreement, as if they've just concluded a deal. Hub and Garth walk Walter back to the car

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The relatives sit beaming at Hub and Garth with phony smiles: they're still here. Hub looks over at Walter:

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: So, kid! How's that root beer? Walter sips a huge root beer, nods: it's good. Then, he blinks: the relatives now glare murderously at him. Hub and Garth lean back, satisfied: "The Plan" is working. Helen gives Ralph a "go on" sign. He clears his throat: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHITE Revision - 8/25/02 23. 38

dialogues.speaker: RALPH
dialogues.text: Uncle Hub, Uncle Garth, this has been such a wonderful weekend, so I hate to bring this up: but did you two look at those wills I left you? Hub and Garth shake their heads, and SPIT. RALPH (Cont'd) It's best to be prepared...

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: We ain't planning on dying any time soon.

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: Speak for yourself!

dialogues.speaker: RALPH
dialogues.text: You both need to be thinking about these things, at your age. GRAVEL CRUNCHES: a car pulls up. A salesman. Hub and Garth smile, jack rounds into their shotguns: KA-CHUNK KA Helen SHRIEKS. Walter covers his ears. Below, this SMART SALESMAN leaps out and quickly crouches down behind his car, safe behind cover

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: Damn!

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: He's been here before....

dialogues.speaker: SMART SALESMAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Don't shoot! Safe behind his car, the salesman waves a white flag.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: This is no ordinary salesman...!

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: I like a challenge.

dialogues.speaker: SMART SALESMAN
dialogues.text: Brothers McCann! Let's talk

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: Come out where we can see you! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHITE Revision - 8/25/02 24. 38

dialogues.speaker: SMART SALESMAN
dialogues.text: Put down your guns! Then I'll come out!

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: This guy is good.

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: I'll cover him, you sneak around.... Walter tugs at Hub's shirt; Hub wheels around, SNAPS: HUB (Cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: W-W-Why not see what he's selling?

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: What the hell for?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: M-M-Maybe it's something you want! To b-b-buy! Hub and Garth exchange flabbergasted looks: it's never occurred to them. This greatly upsets the relatives:

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Your uncles know better than to squander their money like that Helen yanks Walter away, but Walter still calls out:

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: But what good is having all that money if you never spend any? (relatives look alarmed) It's no good to you after you're gone! Ralph's hands reach for Walter's neck. The uncles think:

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: Could be, the kid has a point...!

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: We'll see what the man's selling... then we shoot him.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: Good plan! Both lower their shotguns and amble toward the salesman. Relatives GROAN. Walter breaks away and follows.  WHITE Revision - 8/25/02 25.

dialogues.speaker: THE SALESMAN BESIDE HIS CAR 39
dialogues.text: The wary, sweaty Salesman sees the brothers approach.

dialogues.speaker: SMART SALESMAN
dialogues.text: Gentlemen! After our previous unsettling encounters, I've searched the world over for the perfect item for two exuberant sportsmen such as yourselves. And I've found it! He pops open his trunk, removes a large contraption. SMART SALESMAN (Cont'd) Voila!

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: SMART SALESMAN
dialogues.text: The sport of kings! Up to now, only Heads of State could afford a fine piece of equipment like this. And it's simple enough this child can operate it!

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: SMART SALESMAN
dialogues.text: My boy, just press this button... Walter presses a button: a powerful arm flings a clay pigeon skyward. The salesman grabs a shotgun out of his trunk, swings it up, and KA-POW! He blasts the clay pigeon. Hub and Garth GASP: it's Love At First Sight.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: wow!

dialogues.speaker: SMART SALESMAN
dialogues.text: The most powerful machine on the market! And very reasonably priced! The relatives all scowl and BABBLE:

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Why, that's the biggest waste of money I've ever...!

dialogues.speaker: RALPH
dialogues.text: Mister, you load up that contraption and get the hell out.... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: And all the targets and ammunition you can get!

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Oh_ no you don't! I won't have my children around all this gun- foolishness!

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: Then LEAVE! Garth pulls out a huge money-wad, peels off big bills. Helen fumes, storms off; her furious family follows. As Garth counts out money, the Salesman nearly faints: the once-in-a-lifetime moment every salesman dreams of. The relatives drive away: all glare daggers at Walter.

dialogues.speaker: THE FRONT PORCH
dialogues.text: EVOCATIVE MUSIC PLAYS. Walter stares, stunned, at the front porch heaped with cases of targets and ammo.

dialogues.speaker: LAKE SHORE
dialogues.text: Walter, with make-shift hearing protection, loads up the skeet machine, pulls the handle. CLANG! Clay pigeons WHOOSH out over the lake. Hub and Garth BLAST away, never miss.

dialogues.speaker: A SEED SALESMAN 42
dialogues.text: Walter watches Garth select a variety of colorful seed packets from a SEED SALESMAN. Nearby, Hub scowls.

dialogues.speaker: THE GARDEN 43
dialogues.text: The uncles and Walter finish planting and admire their handiwork. Hub pulls out his pouch of chewing tobacco, gets a plug; he holds the pouch out to Garth, who takes some. Without thinking, Hub then holds it out to Walter. Walter anxiously peers deep into the tobacco pouch. Bravely, he takes the smallest possible piece, puts it in his mouth, chews... and SWALLOWS. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Walter instantly turns green and starts GAGGING. Garth SLAPS him on the back and glares at Hub. Walter gives Hub a pained look of "How could you?" Hub scowls.

dialogues.speaker: THE GARDEN 44
dialogues.text: A sprout has just broken the soil. Beyond, Walter lies on the ground, stares at it, amazed. The MUSIC ENDS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The house is dark, except for a light high up in the towe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter sits in bed, stares at the evocative picture of the mysterious beautiful woman. The ARABIC THEME PLAYS. A door SLAMS downstairs. Walter jumps up, looks out: Garth walks toward the barn. Walter runs downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter peers in: Garth pushes aside hay bales, reveals... a trapdoor in the floor. Garth descends into the ground. Walter GASPS: frightened, but fascinated. He skulks up near the hole, peers down... he hears GARTH CLIMBING BACK UP. He leaps into a pile of hay, burrows deep inside. Garth emerges, counting a big wad of cash. He pushes hay bales back into place and leaves. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: WALT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Ahhh-choo! Inside the haystack, two eyes open wide with wonder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A flashlight CLICKS on, Walter GASPS: the room is heaped with canvas money bags. Bank bags. Loose bills lay scattered everywhere. Walter inspects one bag's lettering "First Bank of New York". Suddenly: ARF! ARF! Startled, Walter looks up: above, the dogs and pig stare down at him curiously.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Oh! You scared me! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHITE Revision - 8/25/02 28. 48 49

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Walter and the animals look at all the money. WALTER (Cont'd) This money look stolen to you? (the dogs look suspicious) Yeah. Me too. Walter thinks. He comes to a decision. WALTER (Cont'd) There's something we gotta do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dogs and pig watch Walter dig a hole. Walter picks up: the Santa Claus costume.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: If the cops find this Santa Claus costume, the uncles go to jail and we're all homeless. The dogs seem to understand. The pig SNIFFS the costume, allows Walter to bury it. Walter TAMPS down the covered hole. There. Then, the dogs BARK, run off. Curious, Walter follows, sees: at the lake's edge, Hub stands looking far out over the water. It's eerie. WALTER (Cont'd) U-u-uncle Hub? No answer. Walter shivers, finally reaches out to Hub... but a hand grabs him, Walter YELPS: it's Garth.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: Don't. I tried to wake him once, he nearly took my head off. Let's give him a few minutes.... (realizes) What are you doing out this late? Walter shrugs innocently. They sit on a rise, overlooking the lake. Hub stands there, motionless. The wind BLOWS.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: What's wrong with him?

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: Well... A man's body grows old, but inside, his spirit can be as young and restless as ever. And him... in his day, he had more spirit than twenty men. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHITE Revision - 8/25/02 29.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Walter nods: Hub stares far out over the distant horizon.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: It looks like... he's looking for something. Garth SIGHS sadly... and finally nods. WALTER (Cont'd) What? What's he looking for?

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: He's looking for her.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Who? What was her name? Long pause. Finally, Garth answers.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: Jasmine. Walter wonders, eyes wide, remembering the photo he found

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: OK! Tell me. The dogs and pig gather closer, as if to listen themselve

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: You want me to tell the story? Now? It'll take days....

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: There's no TV: what else have we got to do?

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: Much of it's second, third hand. Rumors, really. I wasn't there for some of it, and Hub damn sure won't talk about it. Walter nods and waits, eyes pleading. Garth SIGHS. GARTH (Cont'd) Well. My brother was always too restless for Texas. So he convinced our folks he needed to go to Europe. And that I needed to come along. That was the summer of 1914. A STEAMSHIP WHISTLE BLOWS. Walter's mind whirls:  WHITE Revision - 8/25/02 30. 50 51 52 53

dialogues.speaker: WALTER'S IMAGINATION
dialogues.text: YOUNG HUB AND GARTH, both late teens, leave a ship and enter an exotic French port, full of colorful characters.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Unfortunately, just as we arrived in France, so did the Kaiser and the entire German army. They see headlines: "Germany Invades!" GARTH (Cont'd) I wanted to go home, but Hub said we'd tour Europe one step ahead of the Germans. So we did. What a time that was! I remember these girls from Toulon. Twins! We....

dialogues.speaker: GARTH AND WALTER 51
dialogues.text: Garth catches himself, COUGHS, skips that part.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: Anyway... eventually, we wound up in Marseilles, with passage booked on the last ship out of Europe, leaving in the morning. My brother decided we should spend our last night enjoying the local nightlife.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER'S IMAGINATION
dialogues.text: A WILD BAR: full of CAN-CAN GIRLS, SAILORS, SOLDIERS.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: He made friends with some soldiers. They bought us drinks: strange, strong drinks.... We woke up ona ship, bound for North Africa. Shanghaied.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Shanghaied!

dialogues.speaker: WALTER'S IMAGINATION
dialogues.text: The brothers wake up, disoriented. Other SHANGHAIED MEN waken in the same state. A SERGEANT yells orders. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BLUE Revision - 11/3/02 31. 53 54

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: We found ourselves in the French Foreign Legion. "It's all my fault", my brother said. He told me not to worry, he'd make sure nothing happened to me.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER'S IMAGINATION
dialogues.text: In a narrow front-line trench, Garth ducks: TWO ARABS on horseback fly past just overhead. He leaps up, panics: an ARAB HORSEMAN looms over him, sword high: Garth's a goner. But then: Hub flies in, tackles the Arab, finishes him, grins at his brother. Garth SIGHS, smiles his thanks

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: And, in four long years of fighting all over North Africa, battling Germans, Turks, and Arabs, nothing ever did. He saved my life countless times....

dialogues.speaker: WALTER'S IMAGINATION
dialogues.text: TURKS with ladders attack a fortress wall: Garth tries to fire, but his rifle's jammed... a huge TURK looms, sword raised. Garth lamely fumbles for his sword... Hub flies in, snatches up his rifle and SWINGS: arms flail as the TURKS on the ladder fall away. Hub grins, hurries off.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: We fought in many battles, against overwhelming odds, against countless enemies, all fierce and worthy, every one.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER'S IMAGINATION
dialogues.text: Greatly outnumbered, Garth fights with swords on horsebac A HUGE ARAB knocks Garth off his horse, he falls, can't stand: his leg is broken. Helpless, Garth sees his comrades fall: a line of ARABS, GERMANS, and TURKS overru the front line, SCREAMING... He's done for. But then: out of the smoke, Hub gallops in, swings Garth up behind him, they ride away, the last survivors of the epic battl

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: He was promoted to Captain, me to Lieutenant.  55 56 BLUE Revision - 11/3/02 31A.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: After the war, we went our separate ways... I ended up leading safaris, mostly for writers and Hollywood folk. But that was too tame for Hub. He got commissions from the new North African governments to put an end to the slave trade....

dialogues.speaker: WALTER'S IMAGINATION
dialogues.text: Horsemen top a hill: young Hub and his Bedouin GALLOP into a encampment. CLANG! Swords collide, SLAVETRADERS fight; VEILED ARAB WOMEN, prisoners tied together, WAIL. Hub frees the women, then single-handedly stands off a counter-attack. The women all watch him, amazed. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHITE Revision - 8/25/02 32. 56 57 58 59

dialogues.speaker: GARTH, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: No one, slavetrader or Bedouin alike, had ever seen anything like him, this mad American who fought like twenty men....

dialogues.speaker: WALTER 57
dialogues.text: Walter, all ears and wide eyes, hangs on every word.

dialogues.speaker: OUT HERE IN THE MIDDLE OF THE NIGHT
dialogues.text: Walter jumps: Hub looms over them.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: Just enjoying the cool night air.

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: Neither one of you got a lick of sense! Go to bed! Hub storms toward the house, shaking his head. Garth and Walter exchange shrugs, stand, and follow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter's hand retrieves the mail, a lot of mail-order catalogs. Then, Walter sees a letter from "Mae Caldwell".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter rips open the letter, reads....

dialogues.speaker: MAE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: "Dear Walter. How are you? Found your uncles' money yet?" (Walter frowns) "Here I am at school in Fort Worth my nose to the Court Reporting grindstone...." Walter looks at the envelope, stares at the postmark "Las Vegas, Nevada. America's Fun-Tier!" He crumbles the letter. He sits, eyes wet. SNIFFLES. Inside the screen door, Garth watches, looks thoughtful.

dialogues.speaker: HUB, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Damn you, brother! I'm not going anywhere looking like this! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHITE Revision - 8/25/02 33. 59 60

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Hub pushes Garth Hub out onto the porch: both wear stiff new bib-overalls and straw hats, price tags fluttering. HUB (Cont'd) I look like a damn sharecropper!

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: We're gardening! This is what gardeners wear! Hub stalks off. Garth turns to Walter GARTH (Cont'd) I bought you some clothes. They're up in your room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hub, Garth, and Walter hoe: all three wear new bib-overal and straw hats. The plants are knee-high now, identical. Walter watches Hub, fascinated: Hub attacks the ground as if it was a fight to the death.

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: We need this much damn garden?

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: Think how good all these vegetables are gonna taste. Peas, beans squash, tomatoes.... Walter scans the garden: it's all identical knee-high green stalks, every plant just alike. He wonders...

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: What's this row? Garth glances at the row's seed packet on a stake.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: Beets.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: And what's this row?

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: Cabbage. Garth rows, unconcerned. Walter suspiciously compares the beets and cabbages, back and forth: identical.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Aren't beets red smelly things? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHITE Revision - 8/25/02 34.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: That's how they look in cans. This is how they look growing in the field. Now Hub looks suspicious; Walter points to a third row.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: What's this row?

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: Uhh.... Potatoes.

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: Now wait one damn minute! What's this row? Garth looks. The packet shows a big bushy plant of:

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: Tomatoes.... Now Garth knows something's wrong. Hub storms through, YANKING up seed packet stakes that don't match their rows

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: Lettuce! Squash! Sweet potatoes! Carrots! Bok Choi... Bok Choi?

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: A type of Chinese cabbage....

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Hey! This row looks right. They join Walter. Only this packet's photo looks like its row; in fact, just like all the other rows....

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: Corn.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: All the seeds did look alike, come to think of it....

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: Yeah! Like corn!

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: ...but I figured that's how all seeds are supposed to look....

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: Nothing but corn! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHITE Revision - 8/25/02 35. 60 61

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: Boy. That seed salesman sure saw us coming....

dialogues.speaker: CORN
dialogues.text: Fratricide appears imminent. Garth is saved by: HONK! A truck carrying big crates pulls in: a giraffe's head sticks far out of one crate. The brothers grin, excited: HUB (Cont'd) It's here!

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: Kid! Help him unload! we'll be right back! They hurry toward the house. Walter goes to the truck

dialogues.speaker: THE TRUCK 61
dialogues.text: The truck says "Acme Animal Movers". Walter peers into one crate's opening... and YELPS, leaps back as a lion paw darts out, just misses him. ROAR!

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: Watch it kid. He's a man-eater. Walter nods, eyes wide. The DRIVER consults a clipboard. DRIVER (Cont'd) This the McCann place? (Walter nods) We brought your lion. Sign here. ROAR! Walter GULPS, signs.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: But, but... where'd it come from? The driver SNAPS his gum, checks his clipboard.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: Cincinnati. The bored HELPER leans on the truck and picks his teeth.

dialogues.speaker: HELPER
dialogues.text: King of da beasts. Terror of da jungle. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHITE Revision - 8/25/02 36.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: Quit yakking and help me unload. Hub and Garth hustle up: both wear new safari clothes and pith helmets, price tags fluttering. They noisily load big bullets into new huge rifles. The truckers exchange "now I've seen everything" looks. DRIVER (Cont'd) So. Where do you want him?

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: Right here will be just fine. Ammo dry, Hub and Garth stand ready. The truckers start to unload a crate; it says "Cincinnati Zoo" on the side.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: You bought a lion? A used lion?

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: Stand back kid. You don't want to get mauled and eaten. ROAR! The brothers grin. GARTH (Cont'd) Listen to him!

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: A big one!

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: Brother, this was the best idea you ever had!

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: This lion head'1l sure look good hanging over our fireplace.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: What fireplace? You don't have a fireplace!

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: We'll buy one.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: You're gonna shoot it? The crate is down. Another ROAR: but the ROARS all comes from another crate, one still on the truck (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHITE Revision - 8/25/02 37.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: Hey! This the right crate? The driver checks a clipboard, nods.

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: We want that lion!

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: It's going to Fresno. Garth puts an ear to their crate: he hears nothing.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: You sure there's a lion in here?

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: Absolutely! Be seein' ya!

dialogues.speaker: HELPER
dialogues.text: Nice cornfield you got there! The truck pulls away. All stare at the silent crate. Hub kicks it. Nothing. Garth listens again:

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: I hear breathing. He's in there all right! On the soundtrack, AFRICAN DRUMS begin to BEAT. LOUDER. Hub aims at the crate as Garth unhooks the crate's latche

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: I don't think this is very sporting...

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: Kid, at our age, this is as sporting as we get.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: Walter, come here. Garth lifts the wary Walter atop the crate. GARTH (Cont'd) When I give the word, pull this. The uncles raise their rifles. Drums BEAT LOUDER, FASTER.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Maybe I should have a gun too. Just in case.... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHITE Revision - 8/25/02 38. 61

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: Pull!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter sweats, pulls, ducks. The crate side falls, SPLAT! Hub and Garth aim, the DRUMS BEAT TO A CRESCENDO... and nothing happens. The DRUMS TRAIL OFF. Pause. Walter peeks between his fingers.

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: Hey! Come on out of there! Nothing. All look in: a mangy lion looks out at them.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: Hey you! In the crate! Get your lion butt outta there! Nothing. Walter, still atop the crate, peers in upside- down: the lion just sits there, looking bored. It YAWNS.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: It looks awful tame....

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: This lion's no good! It's... defective!

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: It's alive! That's the main thing!

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: Well then, go ahead! Shoot it!

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: That wouldn't be sporting, shooting it inside a crate!

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: Yeah? So?

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: Wait 'till it sticks its head out. Then we blast it. Garth shrugs: sounds fair enough. Walter peers in.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: He looks old. Worn-out looking.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: Oh! Perfect! It is indeed a pretty sad looking animal. It YAWNS. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHITE Revision - 8/25/02 39.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: He's real old. Look: he's only got two teeth.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: Some lion hunt this is! Walter hops off the crate, takes a step inside.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Here kitty, kitty. Nice kitty.... ROAR! Walter scrambles atop Hub's shoulders. All leap back. Then: COUGH COUGH COUGH, a hacking, old lion cough. WALTER (Cont'd) He's sick! You can't shoot him!

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: Get off me!

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: Defective and dying. A reject! A sick zoo cast-off!

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: So can I keep him? Hub and Garth look at Walter, flabbergasted. WALTER (Cont'd) I'll feed him and take care of him and clean up after him and everything! I never had a pet of my very own! So can I keep him? Huh? Huh? Can I? Hub GROWLS. Hub looks at Walter seriously.

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: So kid. You want to take care of it? Nurse it back to health? (Walter GULPS, nods) Good. Then we shoot it! Hub and Garth head back to the house, arguing:

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: That's some lion you bought...!

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: Yeah? That's some garden seeds you bought...! As Walter closes the crate door, he speaks soothingly: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Don't worry. They're not as bad as they seem right at first.... I'll be right back with supper

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hub and Garth watch Walter at the crate, HAMMERING, SAWIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lion eats, and curiously watches the crate renovation

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dogs and pig watch as Walter removes every other vertical slat, making narrow openings.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: There. Now you can see out. He looks in: the lion BELCHES contentedly. Walter goes. The pig and dog rush up, stick their heads inside. ROAR! All scatter, SQUEALING. From the crate: COUGH-COUGH-COUGH The lion stares out at the thick green jungle of leafy stalks, just out of reach, with an urgent, primal longing JUNGLE DRUMS, JUNGLE SOUNDS ECHO.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter steps up and sits.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: You sure he can't get out?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: (nods) She. It's a girl lion. Hub frowns: it figures. He leans back, SIPS.... WALTER (Cont'd) I named her "Jasmine". Hub CHOKES, bolts upright, furious:

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: Dammit! Have you two been talking about...? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHITE Revision - 8/25/02 41. 65 66

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Garth shrugs innocently. Hub glares at Walter: well?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: I-I-I got it out of a book of Fairy Tales! It just seemed like a good name! For a lion! Hub storms inside, SLAMS the door.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: Thanks a lot! You trying to get me killed? Angry, Garth goes in. Walter wonders, SIGHS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hub, Garth, and Walter follow a FEED STORE OWNER.

dialogues.speaker: FEED STORE OWNER
dialogues.text: Sorry it took awhile to come in. In forty years I never had a call for it. I wouldn'ta believed they even made such a thing. They join others, FARMERS mostly, staring down at a palle stacked with bags marked:

dialogues.speaker: FARMER
dialogues.text: "Purina Lion Chow". I'll be. The farmers scratch their heads in wonder.

dialogues.speaker: FEED STORE OWNER
dialogues.text: If you'll wait a few minutes, my boys will load you up. Hub frowns, grabs a bag, throws it over his shoulder

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: Garth. Pay the man.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: Brother, be careful.

dialogues.speaker: FEED STORE OWNER
dialogues.text: Mr. McCann, those bags weigh fifty pounds apiece.... Hub glares, stalks off. Even the farmers are impressed.  WHITE Revision - 8/25/02 42.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hub tosses the last of the bags into their old farm truck straightens his back. Garth and Walter watch, concerned.

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: There. If you two old ladies want to get in now, we can go home. Hub hops down off the dock... suddenly his eyes roll up in his head: he collapses and he crumples to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: Hub!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ignored by busy HOSPITAL PERSONNEL, Garth and Walter wait anxious: they closely watch a nearby open doorway where hurried NURSES and DOCTORS rush in and out. Walter trudges over to a water fountain.

dialogues.speaker: WATER FOUNTAIN 69
dialogues.text: Walter struggles to operate the water fountain.

dialogues.speaker: MIDDLE-AGED WOMAN
dialogues.text: Psst! Little boy! Walter sees a MIDDLE-AGED WOMAN motion to him. MIDDLE-AGED WOMAN (Cont'd) You're with those McCann brothers? I know about them. She motions him closer, lowers her voice: MIDDLE-AGED WOMAN (Cont'd) I_know... that they're ex-Mafia hit-men, on the run with millions they stole from Al Capone.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Uh huh. Excuse me.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH AND WALTER 70
dialogues.text: Walter joins Garth. They sit silently. Waiting. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHITE Revision - 8/25/02 43.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Tell me more about Africa. About you and Uncle Hub. And Jasmine.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: Why would a smart kid like you want to hear hokey old stories?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: What else we got to do? Walter waits expectantly. Finally, Garth SIGHS.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: OK, OK.... Now where was I?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER'S IMAGINATION
dialogues.text: Young Hub and his Bedouin again scatter slavetraders.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: "No one, slavetrader or Beduoin alike, had ever seen anything like him, this mad American who fought like twenty men..."

dialogues.speaker: GARTH, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Oh yeah, right... TIGHTEN on one particular veiled young WOMAN prisoner. GARTH (0.S.) (Cont'd) It just so happened that one women Hub freed was a handmaiden to a princess.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER'S IMAGINATION
dialogues.text: She is joyfully reunited with her mistress and HANDMAIDEN all wear veils. EUNUCHS stand guard.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: She told her mistress the story of her rescue. Most of all, she told her of the handsome heroic American. The veiled PRINCESS's eyes sing and dance.... GARTH (Cont'd) "I must meet this man," the Princess said.... The women huddle together, GIGGLING. Plotting.  WHITE Revision - 8/25/02 44, 73

dialogues.speaker: WALTER'S IMAGINATION
dialogues.text: Horse hoofs POUND the shoreline.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: One day, Hub rode his horse at dawn, along the Mediterranean. Young Hub rides his magnificent stallion, both horse and rider at the peak of their youth, strength, and power. GARTH (Cont'd) When out of nowhere, there appeared another rider who drew up alongside. An Arab, face covered, turns to ride alongside. GARTH (Cont'd) Well! You know Hub. There was no way he'd let any challenge pass. It became a race.... The two ride at breathless speed, flat-out, neck and neck GARTH (Cont'd) Many considered Hub the finest horseman in North Africa. He'd never lost a horse race, not one. But this rider stayed right with him, neck and neck, as the race went on and on. And on. Hub looks at the mysterious rider in wonder GARTH (Cont'd) Then: a horse stumbled, the horses collided, and both riders flew into the sea. Hub leapt up, his sword drawn, ready for anything. So he thought. He wasn't ready at all for what he saw next.... Hub pulls his sword, whirls... stares: the rider sits up out of the sea, disguise gone, water streams from her long black hair. She meets Hub's eyes, smiles, and LAUGHS GARTH (Cont'd) She was the Princess. She was the most beautiful woman he had ever seen. She was....

dialogues.speaker: WALTER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Jasmine! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHITE Revision - 8/25/02 45. 73 74 75

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She is, of course, the woman from the picture: Jasmine. Hub laughs. And the two look into each other's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Now most people don't believe in such things nowadays: they say it's something you only find in stories. But when those two first laid eyes on each other, it was honest-to-god, no-kidding, sure- enough, once-in-a-lifetime... "Love At First Sight". MUSIC SWELLS. The horses caper and court in the surf behind the couple who have eyes only for each other.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER 74
dialogues.text: Walter listens blissfully; then his eyes focus, he realiz Garth has finished. Walter becomes more and more bothered

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. Where is she? Garth looks at him, surprised. Walter talks in a rush. WALTER (Cont'd) If it was true love they would have gotten married and lived happily ever after and she'd be right here with us now! Right? A shadow of sadness sweeps across Garth's face.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: Aren't you jumping ahead of the story?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Well... OK. Keep going.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: Well... Things weren't easy for them, back then: they were from different worlds. She was from a royal family, her father a Sultan. But none of that mattered to them. They arranged often, to meet....

dialogues.speaker: WALTER'S IMAGINATION
dialogues.text: Jasmine swoops up behind a waiting Hub. They embrace. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHITE Revision - 8/25/02 75 76 77 78 79

dialogues.speaker: GARTH, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: They made plans to run away together. But there was one big problem: she was promised to another man, a powerful Sheik from a nearby kingdom, an evil Sheik who wore a patch over one eye.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER'S IMAGINATION
dialogues.text: CLOSE-UP: An Arab whirls around and glares: the SHEIK with one eye. An evil, brutal-looking, ugly old man.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Surprisingly, despite his ruthless ways, the evil Sheik was said to be quite young and handsome....

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Walter jumps, startled. He rewinds his imagination:

dialogues.speaker: WALTER'S IMAGINATION
dialogues.text: An Arab whirls and glares, a different SHEIK: this Sheik' young and handsome, but still one nasty customer. WIDEN, REVEAL: in Jasmine's father's palace, the Sheik threatens

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: a kind-looking Sultan, JASMINE'S FATHER.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: The evil Sheik heard Jasmine loved another: he threatened her father to hand Jasmine over at once, for their wedding to take place that very night. Her father had no choice. And so the evil Sheik took Jasmine off to his kingdom and locked her away in his harem.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER'S IMAGINATION
dialogues.text: Imprisoned in a fabulous harem, Jasmine SOBS. OTHER WIVES try to comfort her, but Jasmine will have none of that.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: She told the other wives she'd rather die than to be a wife to the evil, heartless Sheik. She hid away a knife, so that when the Sheik came for her that night, she could slit her own throat.... 46. 75 76 77 78 79  WHITE Revision - 8/25/02 47. 80 81 82 83

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Oh! What did Uncle Hub do?!

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: Why, he rescued her, of course...

dialogues.speaker: WALTER'S IMAGINATION
dialogues.text: Swords CLANG! Hub fights his way through the harem, past WARRIORS and EUNUCHS; wives point him to an alcove where. ...knife poised, Jasmine is about to end her life. Hub slashes the curtain aside. She is saved.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: As they galloped for the gates of the city, there was only one horseman brave enough to stand in their way: the Sheik.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER'S IMAGINATION
dialogues.text: On horseback, the Sheik waits ominously, sword drawn.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: It was a thrilling battle on horseback, between two expert swordsmen... but Hub drew first blood, a mighty stroke that cut a big long scar down the side of the sheik's once-handsome face. After a short but thrilling swordfight, Hub and Jasmine race through the gates, toward the desert and freedom. GARTH (Cont'd) They galloped away, got married, and lived together happily ever after. The End.

dialogues.speaker: THE HOSPITAL 83
dialogues.text: Walter revels in the story's after-glow. But then....

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: But wait! If they lived happily ever after, she'd be here. So where the heck is she?! Didn't they have kids? Where are they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 83 84 PINK Revision - 11/3/02

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Garth looks sad and evasive. A NURSE exits Hub's room.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: Nurse! What's going on? (she hurries off) I wish somebody'd tell us something! Anxious, both turn to Hub's doorway. Suddenly, medical supplies fly out of the room, SMASH against the wall.

dialogues.speaker: HUB, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Where the hell are my pants?! Garth and Walter sit back and EXHALE, relieved. CRASH: DOCTORS and NURSES spill out: Hub storms out, head bandaged, wearing a hospital gown, carrying his clothes trailing an I.V. bottle. He glares at Garth and walter HUB (Cont'd) Who brought me here? You two? Garth and Walter shake their heads innocently.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: The three ride along in silence: of course, Hub drives.

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: Hospitals! Lot of good they are!

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: How would you know? You're never in one long enough to find out! Hub scowls; sweating, he squirms, tries to ease his back pain. Garth and Walter see it, know it's getting worse. GARTH (Cont'd) Hey! You missed the turn!

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: Did not!

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: Home is that way!

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: I want to go THIS way! Ahead out the front windshield, Walter sees the familiar gas station/country store now draped with new signs: (CONTINUED)
Hub glares, storms for the exit. Walter and Garth hurry after him. 83 84  84 85 PINK Revision - 11/3/02

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: "Now selling BARBECUE!" "Ribs! Sausage! MEAT!"

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Wow! Look at that! That's why we went this way, huh Uncle Hub? Let's stop! Hub nods, pulls over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SLAP!: atop butcher paper, huge slabs of ribs, brisket, and sausage are piled high by a SCRAWNY OLD WOMAN OWNER. At a long bar-like counter, Walter, Hub, and Garth dig in. Walter eats his barbecue, but he's all ears.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: Brother, someday you're going to have to start acting your age.

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: What the hell does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: Your whole life, you've never been afraid of anything. So what's eating at you now? Gettin' old? Dying?

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: Hell no!

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: What then? What?

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: Being useless! Pause. Finally Garth nods, he understands. HUB (Cont'd) Me and you, we shoulda died in the last battle of the last war.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: Unfortunately, we lived.

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: It's a damn shame! All around us people died, good people. And we didn't, we're still here. Why? What the hell for? (CONTINUED)
84 85 + ee OF

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 85 86 PINK Revision - 11/3/02

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: When we were young there was always a reason. A point. Things made sense. There were always things worth dying for. Freedom. Honor Virtue. Now there's no point to anything. What do we do? We garden.... We outlived our time.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: Maybe there's still things worth living for, brother... BURP! Startled, Hub and Garth look over at Walter: he grins, embarrassed, his face smeared with grease.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Good barbecue!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bearing "Get Well" balloons, relatives peer into Hub's room: they see an empty bed. Helen grabs a DOCTOR.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Doctor! Where's Mr. McCann?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Oh. I'm afraid he's gone.... The relatives try to hide joyful smirks and look somber

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Finally!

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Well, he led a long, full life... where's the body?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: No, he's gone. Left. Mr. McCann checked himself out....

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Left? But...! On the phone, it sounded serious! All look crushed. Martha pouts, STAMPS her foot:

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: I'll never get a pony! 50. 85 86  87 PINK Revision - 11/3/02

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: These days, nothing makes sense. Nothing matters. Through double screen-doors, a convertible SCREECHES UP music BLARING. FOUR HOODS jump out: leather jackets duck tails. They SLAM open both doors, swagger in, stare around insolently as if they own the place. Walter watches the old woman scurry into a door marked "Ladies Room". SLAM. CLICK: she locks the door. Three hoods help themselves to six-packs from a cooler The leader, FRANKIE, sees the uncles, swaggers over.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Hey! Old man! How's that barbecue? Gimmie some!

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: Get lost, boy. We're busy here.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: What? What did you say? Hub shakes his head, continues to Garth:

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: Here's a perfect example of what I'm talking about. Since this boy was suckling on his momma's teat he's been given everything but discipline. Now his idea of courage and manhood is to get together with a bunch of punk friends and ride around irritating folks too good-natured to put a stop to it. Garth nods sadly. The punks are flabbergasted:

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: What? Who do you think you are, old man? Huh? Frankie pushes Hub against the bar. Hub's eyes blaze.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: Hub: he's just a dumb kid. Don't kill him. The punks LAUGH. Frankie takes a fighting stance. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 87 + ee OF x  87 PINK Revision - 11/3/02 52.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Ha! Hey old man! Answer me! Who do you think you are? Huh? Frankie swings... but Hub dodges easily. Hub grabs the punk's throat, squeezes hard, lifts him off the ground. Frankie GAGS. Hub's fierce eyes drill deep into the startled, helpless punk's eyes. Hub GROWLS:

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: I'm Hub McCann. I've fought in two world wars and countless smaller ones on three continents. I've led thousands of men into battle with everything from horses and swords to artillery and tanks. I've seen the headwaters of the Nile and tribes of natives no white men had ever seen before. I've won and lost a dozen fortunes killed many men, and loved only one woman with a passion a flea like you could never begin to understand. That's who I am. Walter's huge eyes shine. HUB (Cont'd) Now. Go home... boy. With one last patented-Hub-look, Hub tosses Frankie away.

dialogues.speaker: HOOD
dialogues.text: You're the McCann brothers? We know all about you!

dialogues.speaker: HOOD
dialogues.text: Everybody in town says you're escaped Nazi war criminals! Walter rolls his eyes. Frankie pulls a switchblade: CLICK

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Come on! We'll show this old bastard who's tough. The others pull knives: CLICK. CLICK. CLICK. KA-CHUNK. In the store's doorway, Garth now levels a shotgun at the punks.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: Now boys, you're fixing to let those teenage hormones get you into a world of trouble. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 87  WHITE Revision - 8/25/02 53. 87

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The pale hoods drop their knives. And Hub is furious.

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: Damn it Garth! Did I ask you to butt in?!

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: You just got out of the hospital!

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: Hell, there's only four of em!

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: OK, fine. You fight him... (nods at Frankie) ...then I'll let you fight the rest of 'em. OK? Peeved, Hub knows better than to argue, nods angrily. The hoods look confused. Garth points to Frankie. GARTH (Cont'd) Hey, you. Pick up that knife.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: Son, you need all the help you can get. Frankie snatches up his knife, crouches in front of Hub and SWISHES the knife back and forth dramatically.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Come on, old man!

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: You're holding the knife wrong.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Huh? When Frankie glances at his knife, Hub chops his arm, the knife flies away, Hub elbows the hood hard in the face. Garth turns to the other hoods, shakes his head:

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
