dialogues.text: Sheesh. Oldest trick in the book With a HOWL, Frankie rushes Hub, SLAMS into him, fists flailing: The Fight Is On. The boy flails at Hub, lands an occasional blow, but mostly just expends energy. Hub, however, calmly and collectedly takes the young man apart (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 87 88 PINK Revision - 11/3/02

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Frankie manages a lucky shot, bloodies Hub's nose. Hub touches it, surprised; he smiles, actually pleased. Walter watches, amazed. The hoods can't believe it:

dialogues.speaker: HOODS
dialogues.text: Frankie's losing!

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: Then you three better get in there and help him. The other hoods charge in. And, for a minute, it appears Hub is at a disadvantage.... But not for long. Anxious, Walter joins Garth: Garth casually cleans his fingernails with one of the hood's switchblades.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: How come you're not helping?

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: My brother always hogs the bad guys. He's selfish that way.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: But there's four of 'em...! One hood SLAMS against the bar beside them, SLIDES to the ground, unconscious. WALTER (Cont'd) ...three of 'em! Couldn't you both share?

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: Naa. After forty years, I'm used to it. Besides... right now, he needs them worse than I do. Hub fights, a grin on his face: he's having the most fun he's had in years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The relatives arrive at the house, look around:

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: They're not home yet.

dialogues.speaker: RALPH
dialogues.text: I'm sure, with Hub just out of the hospital, they're taking it slow and easy on the way home. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHITE Revision - 8/25/02 55. 88 89 90

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Helen nods, he's right. The kids scatter, SCREAMING. The two wild boys spot the crate by the cornfield.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: Beats me. Let's tear it up!

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. THE LION'S CRATE 89
dialogues.text: The lion sleeps. SAW! HAMMER! CREAK! She opens one eye, sees two boys working furiously on the crate. CREAK: one side of the crate SLAMS to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: What is it? A lion rug?

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: No, stupid! It's stuffed! The boys jump on the lion, tugging its ears. Then: GROWL!

dialogues.speaker: AAAAGGGHHH
dialogues.text: The boys run off SCREAMING. The lion COUGH-COUGHS, lazily stands, stretches. She stares at the chest-high cornfield; it beckons to her: jungle drums SOUND, exotic birds SHRIEK. She pads out of the crate and disappears into the cornfield-jungle.

dialogues.speaker: BOYS
dialogues.text: Momma! A lion tried to eat us! Helen whirls around and SLAPS them.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: What have I told you about those lies of yours?! The boys BAWL. A car engine ROARS: the uncles' truck PULLS UP fast, BRAKES hard. Garth and Walter leap out.

dialogues.speaker: RALPH
dialogues.text: Where's Uncle Hub? What have you done with Uncle Hub? The convertible SCREECHES UP: A bruised, happy Hub drives with four badly beaten passengers, all GROANING. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHITE Revision - 8/25/02 56. 90

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Lord! There's been an accident!

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: It was a fight! Uncle Hub won! It_was great!

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: Kid! Go get some meat! Beside Hub, Frankie presses a rag to his bloody nose:

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: I wadda doe hobe now!

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: You're in no shape to go home now... GROANS from corpses in the rear. Walter runs up with steaks: Hub and Garth slap the steaks onto black eyes.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Those are the biggest hoods in the whole county! And you brought them home?

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: We couldn't leave 'em lying in the roadway. The little boys still BAWL: Helen SMACKS them.

dialogues.speaker: BOYS
dialogues.text: But momma! There is a lion!

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Oh! Jasmine! (to Hub and Garth) I gotta feed Jasmine! She hasn't eaten all day! I bet she's really hungry! The uncles nod distracted. Walter runs off with a steak.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Jasmine? And who is Jasmine?

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: The boy's lion.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Lion? You got a lion?

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: It's locked up. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHITE Revision - 8/25/02 57. 90 91 92 93

dialogues.speaker: BOYS
dialogues.text: No it isn't! It tried to EAT us! Everybody freezes, stunned, as the implications sink in.

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: The kid. Where'd he go?

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: To feed the lion. Said it was hungry, hadn't eaten all day.... Everyone's eyes go wide at the dire implications.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Here kitty, kitty. Nice kitty.... Walter peers into the remains of the crate. No lion. Then, in the nearby cornfield: CORNSTALKS RUSTLE, a movin trail of shaking stalks, like the wake of a submerged shark... it heads straight toward Walter WALTER (Cont'd) Jasmine...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Lion's P.0.V. through the "jungle": DRUMBEATS pound faster and faster, as her P.O.V. bursts out of the "jungle", leaps, and flies toward a startled walter.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Jasmine...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uncles, relatives, and hoods madly tear out of the house, trailing guns and ammunition, sprint toward the cornfield Hub and Garth freeze: in the distance, the lion pins Walt on the ground. Helen SCREAMS. Hub aims.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: Don't shoot! You'll hit him! All run closer, guns raised, faces tense.  WHITE Revision - 8/25/02 58. 94

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: The lion has Walter pinned, eyeball to eyeball.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Oof! Get off me, lion-breath! Jasmine smiles, gives Walter a affectionate lick: SLURP. WALTER (Cont'd) Eeee-yuck! The lion sees everyone approaching, ROARS! It grabs Walter's foot in its mouth, drags him into the "jungle". Walter's rescuers run up and stare at the "jungle's edge" where Walter and the lion have disappeared.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: They're gone! ROAR! SLURP! The rescuers look stricken. All hear LICKING NOISES, SQUEALS, SOUNDS OF STRUGGLE: it sounds dreadful. Helen SCREAMS, faints dead away. THUD.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: We're too late!

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: Move _in! JUNGLE DRUMS POUND. All follow Hub and Garth toward the awful NOISES, tense, guns aimed, prepared for the worst..

dialogues.speaker: WALTER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Jasmine! Stop!

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: Attack! All rush in, guns aimed, and freeze: the lion licks Walte who SQUEALS and tries to temper the lion's wet affection.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Yuck! Lion-spit! Blaah! Walter notices all the guns pointing at them. WALTER (Cont'd) Look! She's feeling a lot better! Walter strokes the lion: she PURRS.

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: Jesus! KID! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHITE Revision - 8/25/02 59. 94 95

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Hub snatches Walter up, lifts him to eye level and frantically inspects him, top to bottom. HUB (Cont'd) You're OK...?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Were you worried about me, Uncle Hub? Hub HARUMPHS... and for once, perhaps the first time ever Hub seems at a loss for what to say.... Then he glares at everyone standing around:

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: You people tryin' to ruin our whole damn crop? Get out of the cornfield!

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Come on kitty! Back in the box! Hub and Garth watch as Walter tries to drag the lion out of the cornfield; the rescue party stumbles out, drops their guns. Two hoods help revive a weak, dazed Helen:

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: A lion! They bought a lion

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: But she's real friendly! See? Walter pulls the lion's tail with all his strength: he's suddenly jerked off his feet back into the cornfield. WALTER (Cont'd) Come on kitty! Lions don't belong in cornfields! Bad kitty! Bad lion! Come! The stunned hoods join the uncles, watch their struggle.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: The animal seems pretty tame. (Hub nods, thoughtful) And if we get rid of it... what are we going to do with a thousand pounds of Purina Lion Chow?

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: That is a consideration. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHITE Revision - 8/25/02 60. 95

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A crazed Helen stumbles up, hat askew, hair a mess.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: We're leaving! And we're not coming back until you get rid of that, that... monster! Walter watches, anxious, as Hub and Garth trade dead-pan looks. Then:

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: The lion stays. Walter CHEERS, the hoods grin. Helen storms off.

dialogues.speaker: CHILDREN
dialogues.text: "Bye Uncle Hub! 'Bye Uncle Garth!

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Shut up! Get in the car! The furious relatives drive away, for the very last time. Finally, Walter leaves the cornfield: he gives up.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: She won't come out of the cornfield! All watch: the lion paces, patrolling her corn-territory.

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: She thinks she's in the jungle.... (all realize he's right) She's a zoo animal. This cornfield's the closest thing to a jungle she's ever seen.... The jungle's in her blood. She knows it's where she belongs. The hoods shake their heads, amazed at all this. Far off, jungle drumbeats ECHO, exotic birds CALL

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: You boys hungry? Wanna stay for supper? The hoods shrug: why not? They follow Garth to the house.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: What are we having? Garth peels the steak off Frankie's face.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: Meat. Lots of meat.... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHITE Revision - 8/25/02 61. 95 96

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Hub and Walter watch the lion pacing.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Look! I think she's happy! Hub nods; then, a rare sight: Hub smiles. Then, more rare, Walter smiles, his first smile in a long, long time

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter and Garth sit, enjoying the evening. Down by the hood's car, Hub intensely lectures to the young men. In the cornfield the lion ROARS happily; COUGH-COUGH-COUGH Garth expertly shuffles a deck of cards, with impressive professional-gambler flourishes, deals a hand of solitair

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: What's he saying to them?

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: He's giving them his "What Every Boy Needs to Know About Being a Man" speech. Below, Hub paces back and forth like Patton addressing the troops. The hoods stand up straighter GARTH (Cont'd) A lot of men have heard that speech over the years. A lot of men.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Will he give the speech to me?

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: Oh, I guarantee it... Assuming he's still around, of course. Walter nods, troubled at that.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: You didn't finish the story. About Uncle Hub and Jasmine.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: Sure I did: "They got married and lived happily ever after. The End." Remember?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: But, what happened after that? What happened to her? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHITE Revision - 8/25/02 62. 96 97 98 99

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: You don't believe all this "Africa" stuff...

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: It's a good story! Please...!

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: Well... After Hub rescued Jasmine, several years passed. Wonderful years.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER'S IMAGINATION
dialogues.text: ANGLES: Hub and Jasmine ride along a romantic beach.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: No two people were ever so happy, so in love. It was perfect.... Except for one thing.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: The Sheik!

dialogues.speaker: WALTER'S IMAGINATION
dialogues.text: The Sheik rants and curses at his followers.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: Yes, the Sheik. He hated Hub for stealing Jasmine and for scarring his face. He put a price on Hub's head: ten thousand pieces of gold a fortune. Assassins came from thousands of miles away....

dialogues.speaker: WALTER'S IMAGINATION
dialogues.text: Hub and Jasmine shop: Hub leans down to smell spices... a knife flies in and quivers just over his head. TWO ASSASSINS with swords leap at them: Hub ducks, SLUGS one; Jasmine throws red pepper in the other's face. He COUGHS, blinded; Hub tosses him into a pile of melons.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: Many dangerous men tried to kill Hub and get the fortune. They turn a corner: THREE ASSASSINS rush them. The lovers dart into a stall: Hub yanks out a tent pole, the awning falls over the assassins, traps them. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Jasmine SIGHS, gives Hub a "Let's go home..." look. GARTH (Cont'd) He and Jasmine had to be on guard every minute of every day.... As Hub and Jasmine exit the bazaar: FIVE MOUNTED ASSASSIN DRAW SWORDS. The lovers run back into the crowd, hotly pursued by five horsemen as they duck and dart through the maze of merchant stalls... Hub ducks: a SIXTH MOUNTED ASSASSIN swings, misses. Hub YANKS him off the horse, leaps up, pulls Jasmine up behin him. They GALLOP away....

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: So how come all those assassins stopped coming? All we get here now are salesman.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: Hub was furious at the constant danger to Jasmine; he knew the Sheik would never stop. There was only one thing to do. So: one day an assassin led Hub, bound in chains, into the Sheik's fortress to claim the ten thousand pieces of gold.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER'S IMAGINATION
dialogues.text: NIGHT. Two riders on horseback approach the Sheik's fortress: a masked Assassin leads Hub, covered with chain Inside, the Sheik's GUARDS surround a face-covered Assass leading the bound Hub before the evil Sheik.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: The Assassin was given bags and bags full of gold, more than most men could carry, as the cruel Sheik ordered that Hub be taken down into the Sheik's notorious "Dungeon of One Thousand, Three Hundred and Eighty-Seven Tortures"....  WHITE Revision - 8/25/02 64. 102 103 104

dialogues.speaker: WALTER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What kind of greedy no-good scum would turn in Uncle Hub for money?

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: Well... I would. Walter GASPS:

dialogues.speaker: WALTER'S IMAGINATION
dialogues.text: As the Assassin juggles his heavy burden of gold, his facecloth slips just enough to reveal... it's Garth.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: A ha! It was a trick! GUARDS lead the helpless, chained Hub into a nightmarish torture chamber. Terrifying HOODED TORTURERS await.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: In the dungeon, I whipped out my sword and singlehandedly killed everyone and freed Hub, without dropping a single gold coin.... Garth whips out a sword, easily defeats the bad guys, and frees a grateful, humble Hub....

dialogues.speaker: WALTER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Wait _a_minute! Wait a minute!

dialogues.speaker: GARTH, WALTER 104
dialogues.text: Walter looks very skeptical.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: You killed all the bad guys? You saved Uncle Hub? And all that time you were carrying hundreds of pounds of gold?

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: You don't believe I killed all those men and saved Hub? Walter shakes his head: nope, he doesn't. Garth SIGHS. GARTH (Cont'd) Well. Maybe Hub helped a little....  WHITE Revision - 8/25/02 65. 105 106

dialogues.speaker: WALTER'S IMAGINATION
dialogues.text: Hub throws off his chains and fights the Sheik's men. Garth fumbles for his pistol, trying not to drop the gold

dialogues.speaker: GARTH, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: We were greatly outnumbered. We fought incredible odds.... Garth tries to juggle gold and aim, but Hub is faster and dispatches Garth's target first. Garth scowls as Hub defeats the bad guys before Garth can fire a single shot. GARTH (Cont'd) Then we split up: we each knew what we had to do.... At the doorway, Hub heroically salutes Garth, runs swiftl away. Garth hobbles out with his heavy burden of gold.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: High in his opulent bed chamber, the Sheik slept. Until he awoke with Hub's sword at his throat.... Hub stands atop the bed, his blade pins the Sheik GARTH (Cont'd) Terrified, the Sheik knew his life was over, that Hub would certainly kill him. Hub smiled... then lowered his blade. He threw the Sheik a sword, honorably offering his lifelong enemy a fair fight. "Defend yourself!" Hub cried. The evil Sheik grins. The fight begins: CLANG-CLANG! And almost instantly, faster than the eye can follow, Hub sends the Sheik's sword flying and pins the Sheik once again, against a pillar, his blade to the Sheik's throat. GARTH (Cont'd) It was over in a second: Hub had humbled him. The Sheik knew he was surely now a dead man, with no right to even beg for mercy.... As Hub smiles and raises his blade high, the Sheik falls to the floor, WHIMPERING, closing his eyes.... And nothin happens. The Sheik looks up: Hub stands in a window. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: GARTH (Cont'd) Hub told him, "Twice, I held your life in my hands. Twice, I gave it back to you. Next time, your life is mine." Hub leaps out into darkness. The Sheik runs up, looks out: far, far below, Hub and Garth GALLOP away into the dark desert night. GARTH (Cont'd) From that moment on, the assassination attempts stopped. Some say it's because the Sheik knew that, next time, Hub would surely return and kill him, as he had promised. The Sheik feels his tender but still-intact throat, and stares after the vanished horsemen. GARTH (Cont'd) Others say that since Hub had twice spared the Sheik's life, the Sheik felt it was a point of honor to allow his enemy to live.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER 107
dialogues.text: Walter smiles blissfully. Either way sounds right.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: Personally, I think the Sheik just got too darn busy once they discovered oil in his kingdom and he became one of the five richest men in the world....

dialogues.speaker: WALTER'S IMAGINATION
dialogues.text: The Sheik, surrounded by gold stacked high to the ceiling looks dazed, helpless with all his wealth.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: What kinda ending is that?! The bad guy gets filthy rich?! What (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PINK Revision - 11/3/02

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: WALTER (Cont'd) the heck kinda story ends that way? ! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: 66A.
dialogues.text: 109  WHITE Revision - 8/25/02 67.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: I just told it the way it happened. Walter looks very confused. Garth deals another hand.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: So that's how you got all your money? The gold from the sheik? Garth does an amazing waterfall of cards a yard long.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: One of the ways.... Walter blinks. Below, Hub watches the hoods drive away.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Hey, wait! You still didn't tell me what happened to Jasmine! After Uncle Hub defeated the Sheik there was nothing standing in their way, right? Then where the HECK is she?! Tell me! Garth puts a finger to his lips: Hub stiffly ascends the porch, plops down into his chair.

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: Those young men will be OK now.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: Will you? Hub leans back painfully, exhales.

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: Damn it. I feel... old.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: You've been busy. Terrorizing doctors and nurses, beating up teenagers, chasing after lions. You've had a full day.

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: Lucky those boys don't know squat about fighting. It won't be long "til the kid here can whup my ass. The more Hub thinks about it, the more it bothers him. HUB (Cont'd) Won't be long, I'll be helpless in a fight. Useless. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHITE Revision - 8/25/02 68. 109

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He looks sad, bitter. It bothers Walter and Garth.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: Brother, you'll feel better ina day or two... Hub waves him quiet, struggles to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: I'm going to bed. G'night kid.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Walter...! Startled, Hub stares at Walter, who panics: WALTER (Cont'd) M-m-my name? It's W-W-Walter. Hub stares. Beat. Walter sweats. Finally Hub nods.

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: "Walter". Doesn't seem... manly enough. How 'bout I call you "walt"?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: 0k. (beams proudly)

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: Goodnight. Walt. He goes inside. Garth can't believe what he's just seen.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Now. Are you finally gonna tell me what happened to Jasmine? Garth smiles, looks cagey, shuffles too casually.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: Nope...!

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: You want to find out what happened to Jasmine... you have to ask him

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: What? Ask Uncle Hub, about Jasmine? Are you crazy?! Look what happened last time! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: But you and he are buddies now. Don't let the fact he's hasn't spoken about it for forty years bother you...

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: I can't ask him! Uncle Garth! Please...?

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: I'm tired of doing all the dirty work around here. If you want the end of the story, you'll have to ask him... Walt. Garth shuffles the cards, looks very pleased with himself Walter looks wide-eyed, trapped.

dialogues.speaker: FISHING ON THE LAKE 110
dialogues.text: Hub, Garth, and Walter sit in a brand-new fishing boat, fishing poles in the water, having no luck. Hub looks impatient as Garth consults a "How to Fish" book. Then Hub spies a fish, whips out a shotgun, BLASTS it. Hub proudly holds up his shot-up prize for Walter to admire. Garth scowls, casts his line, ignores them.

dialogues.speaker: THE CORNFIELD 111
dialogues.text: Hub, Garth, and Walter look at their corn with pride, at its peak: huge golden ears. It's a beautiful sight.

dialogues.speaker: DINNER TABLE 112
dialogues.text: Dinner: a big steak; sausage; and now fresh sweet corn. Hub, dubious, nibbles: it's great. The three eat happily.

dialogues.speaker: BREAKFAST 113
dialogues.text: Breakfast: eggs, Sausage, and corn. Hub and Walter frown.

dialogues.speaker: THE CORNFIELD 114
dialogues.text: Hub, Garth, and Walter harvest corn: bushel after bushel. Jasmine watches curiously. They pluck the ears, leaving the stalks (and the jungle) intact.  WHITE Revision - 8/25/02 70. 115 116 117 118

dialogues.speaker: WALTER AT A ROADSIDE STAND 115
dialogues.text: Walter proudly sits at a home-made roadside stand, surrounded by dozens of bushels of corn. A sign says: "Corn! 25 cents a bushel!" MATCH DISSOLVE TO:

dialogues.speaker: THE STAND
dialogues.text: The stand, now abandoned: no corn has been sold, and the prices are marked down and down until it finally reads, "Corn! Free! Take all you want!"

dialogues.speaker: THE SKEET THROWING MACHINE 117
dialogues.text: Walter sends a clay target flying, reaches into the box for another: it's empty. Now what? A dog runs up, a ear of corn in its mouth to play catch. Walter smiles, puts the corn on the machine: BOING Hub and Garth blast the flying ear of corn out of the sky. Both give Walter "atta boy" grins. SLOW MOTION: ear after ear of corn poetically bites the dust. By the machine, Garth loads up corn from a bushel. Walter wrestles with a shotgun larger than he is, getting lessons from Hub; Walter has a pillow tied to his butt. Walter fires, the recoil knocks him onto his pillow- cushioned-butt. Hub slaps Walter on the back In the cornfield jungle, the lion watches, happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter struggles into his pants: he can't fasten them at the waist, too small. He looks down: they're now too short. With a surprised grin, Walter realizes: he's grown He looks into a murky mirror: he's filled out, his pale complexion now more tanned. Compared to the timid, pale child who arrived in early summer, he's blossomed. A HONK from outside: Walter looks out the window: a truck pulls into the farm carrying an old biplane.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: An airplane?  WHITE Revision - 8/25/02 71. 119

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hub watches DRIVERS unload a broken-down WWI-era biplane. Garth and Walter stare; they're joined by dogs, the pig.. the lion sticks her head out of the cornfield and gapes.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: Hub. . .? Garth and Walter exchange troubled looks. The airplane is a wreck: it rolls off the truck on flat rotten tires. CREAK! The tail swings wildly, held by a single wire. GARTH (Cont'd) Hub! An aeroplane?

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: Yup. Always wanted one.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: You always said you'd never set foot in an aeroplane! That you don't trust them to fall right out of the sky!

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: Yup. They're dangerous, all right. Plenty dangerous.... Hub smiles, a disturbingly dark smile. Walter and Garth circle the plane dubiously: half the propeller is missing Even the animals look worried. Hub calls to the DRIVER: HUB (Cont'd) Does this thing come with a... book, instructions...?

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: Look inside. Hub digs through the cockpit, finds a WWI era dog-eared manual "The Airman's Handbook"

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: h ha!

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: Hub, you don't know the first damn thing about aeroplanes! Hub dramatically and pointedly opens the manual, reads:

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: "To climb, pull back on the stick (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: HUB (Cont'd) To descend, push forward on the stick." See? Everything I need to know is right here Garth CURSES, stalks off. Walter and the animals watch deeply concerned. Hub climbs in; the tail falls off. HUB (Cont'd) A little fixin' up, and she'll be in the air in no time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Garth and Walter sit, waiting for salesmen: but Hub isn't there. Both watch him, down by the barn, hard at work on the airplane; CLANKS and POUNDING sounds are heard.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Maybe it's just a new hobby. Maybe he doesn't really mean to, you know, do anything crazy.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: You think so? Walter shakes his head: he doesn't believe it either GARTH (Cont'd) You ask him yet? About Jasmine? Walter shakes his head "no" GARTH (Cont'd) Well, you better make it quick He goes inside. Walter thinks, agonizing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter purposefully exits the house, carrying a blanket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hub stands at the shoreline, looking out over the water Walter appears, followed by dogs and pig. Walter stretche way, way up, and drapes the blanket over Hub's shoulders. Walter paces, deeply troubled. The animals wonder what's going on. Walter has to talk to Hub, he just has to.... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHITE Revision - 8/25/02 73. 122 123

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Finally, gathering all his courage: he creeps to Hub takes a deep breath... shoves Hub with all his strength and darts away. The dogs YELP, run off. Hub EXPLODES, YELLS, flails, whirls around, starts to come to his sense

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: What the HELL?!!! (see Walter) It's the middle of the night! What in blazes are you... Hub realizes there's a blanket over his shoulders. HUB (Cont'd) Oh. I wondered where all the blankets were coming from.. (sees Walter's look) What is it? What's the matter? Walter tries to speak, but all courage is gone. His mouth opens and closes, but no sounds emerge. HUB (Cont'd) What...? What is it? Walter struggles, makes some progress: SQUEAKING NOISES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HUB (Cont'd) What? You got something to say, spit it out! Walter SWALLOWS HARD, shaking, hyperventilating; he blurt

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: What happened to her, Uncle Hub? What happened to... Jasmine? Hub flinches, as if struck hard by a forceful blow; he churns inside. Walter quivers, ready to run. Finally, Hub turns away, and looks far out over the water WALTER (Cont'd) I have to know. I have to! The wind BLOWS mournfully. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: She died. She died in childbirth. Her and the baby.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER'S IMAGINATION
dialogues.text: Hub, back turned, head bowed, silhouetted before a Mooris arched window. Don't see his face. Don't need to. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Garth rushes in, still wearing safari clothes; he stands helpless, at his brother's side. MATCH DISSOLVE TO:

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE 124
dialogues.text: Hub, stands in the same grief-stricken stance, forty year later: his sorrow and grief still so intense, so cripplin after all those years. Walter's heart breaks in two.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: What did you do?

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: I went back to the only life I knew. Back to The Legion.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER'S IMAGINATION
dialogues.text: Assembled TROOPS see Hub ride in: they SNAP to attention, sad and proud as Hub slowly rides in to rejoin their rank

dialogues.speaker: HUB, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: For the next forty years there was always one more war to fight. Then I got too old and came here.

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: You should go in now. You'll catch cold.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Those stories, about you, about Africa: they're true. Aren't they?

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: It doesn't matter....

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: It does too! Around my mom I hear so many lies I don't know what to believe in....

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: Dammit, if you want to believe in something, believe in it! Just because something isn't true, that's no reason you can't believe in it! Walter blinks, confused. Hub SIGHS.... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHITE Revision - 8/25/02 75.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: HUB (Cont'd) There's a long speech I give to young men. Sounds like you need to hear a piece of it.... (pause) Some times the things that may or may not be true are the things a man needs to believe in the most. That people are basically good. That honor, virtue, and courage mean everything; that money and power mean nothing. That good always triumphs over evil. That true love never dies. Walter's eyes are wet. Perhaps, so are Hub's. HUB (Cont'd) Doesn't matter if they're true or not. A man should believe in those things anyway. Because they are the things worth believing in. Walter thinks, finally nods: he understands. They both watch moonlight ripple the water, both lost in thought.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: That was a good speech.

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: When are you gonna give me the rest of the speech?

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: When you're ready.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: When's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you're almost a man....

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: OK! You promise? Suddenly, Hub realizes where this is going.

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: Now wait one minute...! Walter goes for broke, speaks in a rush: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHITE Revision 126

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: I really need you to give me the rest of the speech! I can't bea good man unless I hear the whole speech, now can I?!

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: I see what you're trying to pull!

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: So you have to stick around until I'm grown up so you can give the whole speech to me!

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: I'll write it down!

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: No! I want you to give me the speech! Walter starts to cry: Hub looks awkward, at a loss.

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: You won't be living here then...

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: But you're my uncle! I need you to stick around and be my uncle! Hub frowns, feeling more and more trapped. Hub looks WALTER (Cont'd) And what about Uncle Garth? He needs you! He can't fight off all those salesmen by himself! What about the dogs and the pig and the lion?! We all need you!

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: Now you're just being silly.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: No! It's true! We need you! I know you miss Jasmine, an awful, awful lot! But if you go, we'll all miss you! Just as much as you miss her! Just as much! dazed, rocked. Walter BAWLS, a torrent of tears. Hub stares at the boy:Hub looks completely and utterly helpless, for perhaps only the second time in his life. Hub agonizes: he looks trapped. Finally he CURSES, angril throws up his hands. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Face still wet, Walter starts to smile: he knows....

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: All right, dammit! You win! I'll stick around and be your damn uncle! But don't expect me to be happy about it! Hub thrusts out his hand to shake on it. Walter SNIFFLES, grabs Hub in a big hug, mid-thigh. Hub looks startled... then, he reaches down and gently pats Walter's head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter wakes, looks out: in the misty light of pre-dawn, a CAR PULLS UP outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter opens the front door: Mae smiles at him.

dialogues.speaker: MAE
dialogues.text: Walter!

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Mom...?! They hug; a man (STAN) looms behind her. Walter stares.

dialogues.speaker: MAE
dialogues.text: Walter, this is Stan. We're engaged! Isn't that wonderful?

dialogues.speaker: STAN
dialogues.text: Walter! Heard a lot about you!

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Walt. My name is walt.

dialogues.speaker: STAN
dialogues.text: OK. Walt it is. Walter sizes up Stan: a bad comb-over, but he seems friendly enough. Mae hears the uncles' SNORING.

dialogues.speaker: MAE
dialogues.text: Your uncles are still sleeping? It's early, let's not wake them.... They sit on the couch, keep their voices low. Walter sits on a big chair, his feet don't touch the ground. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHITE Revision - 8/25/02 78.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: MAE (Cont'd) Stan here is a detective. A private eye, just like in movies.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Wow! Really?

dialogues.speaker: STAN
dialogues.text: Sure. You want to see my badge? Walter nods. Stan flips open a badge billfold: Walter tries to look closer, but Stan flips it closed.

dialogues.speaker: MAE
dialogues.text: Stan works in Las Vegas. How about that?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: What about Court Reporting School?

dialogues.speaker: MAE
dialogues.text: Oh, I had to quit. Stan wants me to stay home and be a wife and mother. We're gonna buy a house and have lots of kids. You'll have brothers and sisters. Isn't it all wonderful? Stan smiles, nods. Walter looks dazed, stunned. MAE (Cont'd) So Walter. I bet you found where your uncles hid the money, huh? Walter starts to nod, catches himself... looks stubborn.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Why do you want to know? Stan and Mae SIGH sadly; Stan puts his arm around walter.

dialogues.speaker: STAN
dialogues.text: Walt. Your uncles match the description of two bank robbers from the 20's and 30's.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: No. You're wrong!

dialogues.speaker: STAN
dialogues.text: When Mae told me about them, I got copies of the reports and showed them to her. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHITE Revision 128

dialogues.speaker: MAE
dialogues.text: It's them all right, honey.

dialogues.speaker: STAN
dialogues.text: They used shotguns, wore disguises...

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: (weakly) Santa Claus suits?

dialogues.speaker: STAN
dialogues.text: Come to think of it, I believe they did wear Santa Claus suits... Walter trembles. And remains silent. STAN (Cont'd) They stole all that money and shot people. Innocent people.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: No! Not them. It can't be!

dialogues.speaker: MAE
dialogues.text: Stan knows what he's talking about.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: But... what about Jasmine? She and Uncle Hub were in love! TI got her picture!

dialogues.speaker: STAN
dialogues.text: Jasmine...! Wasn't that the name of the woman that drove their getaway car? I think it was, yeah. She was wounded, and they both ran off and left her to die. Walter's breath is knocked out of him; he GASPS. STAN (Cont'd) I know this hurts. But they're criminals and they lied to you. Walter starts to CRY. Mae clutches him to her chest.

dialogues.speaker: MAE
dialogues.text: My poor baby! In the arms of vicious criminals! We rushed here as soon as we knew, we've come to take you away! Now tell Stan where the money is and go pack your things... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHITE Revision - 8/25/02 80. 128 129

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Walter looks up at her.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Why do you need to know where the money is?

dialogues.speaker: STAN
dialogues.text: It's stolen, it doesn't belong to them. Bet it's buried outside, isn't it? Caught off guard, Walter almost nods, catches himself.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: But why do you need to know?

dialogues.speaker: MAE
dialogues.text: Walter! Stan stands, takes out a big flashlight.

dialogues.speaker: STAN
dialogues.text: Walt, let's take a walk. You can show us around the place. At the door, Stan and Mae wait for Walter expectantly; dazed, he joins them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the eerie, shimmering mists of pre-dawn, Stan shines the light around, watches Walter closely for a reaction: as the beam hits the barn, Walter's eyes widen. They walk toward the barn: Stan uses the flashlight and Walter reactions as a divining rod.

dialogues.speaker: STAN
dialogues.text: Now Walter. Your mother and I found this nice house, just like you always wanted. But we don't have enough for a down payment. We could turn your uncles in for the reward, but they'd go to jail... He sees Walter shakes even more as they near the barn. STAN (Cont'd) I know you wouldn't like that. So we thought: with all the money your uncles have, they'd never miss it if we took some. Especially since we're doing them such a big favor by keeping our mouths shut. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHITE Revision - 8/25/02 81.

dialogues.speaker: MAE
dialogues.text: Since it's stolen, we have as much right to it as they do.

dialogues.speaker: STAN
dialogues.text: Nobody gets hurt, and we get a nice home and family. See?

dialogues.speaker: MAE
dialogues.text: Isn't it wonderful, Walter? It's what you always wanted! So, Walter.... where is it? Walter's struggles build and build. Ahead, in the early morning mist... the barn looms.

dialogues.speaker: STAN
dialogues.text: C'mon! They're old, they're gonna die soon anyway. You want the government to get it all?

dialogues.speaker: MAE
dialogues.text: We finally have our chance to be happy, honey. Just tell us. They're in front of the barn. Walter shakes, terrified, torn. Then, softly, an Arab flute PLAYS hauntingly. Suddenly, Walter's struggles cease; his trembling stops He's made up his mind. He smiles.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Hub and Garth didn't rob any banks. They were in Africa.

dialogues.speaker: MAE
dialogues.text: Africa? Walter! Be serious!

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Really! They were shanghaied into the Foreign Legion and had adventures for forty years! They couldn't have robbed any banks!

dialogues.speaker: MAE
dialogues.text: Then where'd they get the money?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Well, Uncle Garth ransomed Uncle Hub to this rich evil Sheik....

dialogues.speaker: MAE
dialogues.text: Walter! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHITE Revision - 8/25/02 82. 129

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: ...who hated Hub for stealing the Princess Jasmine out of his harem and killing all his assassins....

dialogues.speaker: STAN
dialogues.text: Walter, you don't believe that!

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Yeah. Uh-huh. Sure I do!

dialogues.speaker: MAE
dialogues.text: You? Mr. Doubting-Thomas? Here, Stan has actual evidence, and you believe that Africa crap? Walter, you've never believed in anything your entire life! And now you mean to tell me that out of all the things you could have picked to believe in, you believe this? Harems? Princesses? Evil Sheiks? Walter seems as surprised as her.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Yeah...! Isn't that something?

dialogues.speaker: MAE
dialogues.text: Now I want you to think hard. Do you really believe this Africa nonsense? Really and truly? From the bottom of your heart? Walter thinks very, very hard. He seems to search his soul. Then he smiles proudly.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes I do. Mae throws up her hands. Stan takes Walter's arm.

dialogues.speaker: STAN
dialogues.text: Mae, go inside and let us men talk. Man to man. Walter look troubled at this. So does Mae.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Mom...?

dialogues.speaker: STAN
dialogues.text: Go on Mae. We'll be right in. Mae bites her lip anxiously, then nods, walks off. Stan takes Walter by the arm, pulls him into the barn.  WHITE Revision - 8/25/02 83. 130

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter panics as they near the trap door; he struggles.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Let go! Stan SLAPS Walter hard. Walter is stunned. Stan drags Walter to his feet: they're standing on the trap door.

dialogues.speaker: STAN
dialogues.text: Now. Let's me and you get a few things straight: you and me can be friends. Or we can be enemies. The old Walter would have cringed, maybe started crying. But this Walter glares right back STAN (Cont'd) I've had a run of crummy luck lately, and some bad people are looking to make things tough for me. I need that money, I know it's real close, and I'll be damned if some little brat is gonna stand in my way! Walter glares back at Stan with Hub-like murderous fury. STAN (Cont'd) So. Are we friends? Or enemies? Walter smiles. A very cold smile. A very Hub smile. Somewhere, far off, Arabic music PLAYS.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Defend yourself!

dialogues.speaker: STAN
dialogues.text: Huh? Walter kicks the crouching Stan right in the crotch: THUD STAN (Cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: QOOF
dialogues.text: Walter runs out of the barn. Stan stumbles after him: STAN (Cont'd) Come back here!  BLUE Revision - 11/3/02 84. 131 132 133 134 135 136

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter runs, looks back: Stan gains on him. Walter darts toward the cornfield; but Stan tackles him. Stan pins Walter to the ground, SLAPS him hard. Walter SCREAMS. Stan puts his hand over Walter's mouth. Beyond the struggle looms the cornfield. SLAP.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The edge of the cornfield rustles: the lion looks out: she sees Walter pinned on the ground, struggling. SLAP. The lion's eyes narrow fiercely: a look never seen on this lion before. GGGGRRRROOOWWWLLL !

dialogues.speaker: STAN, WALTER
dialogues.text: Stan freezes: what was that? Then, behind him, impossibly fast, comes a speeding lion freight train. The lion SLAMS into Stan, both fly off Walter. GRROWWLL!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dazed, Walter sits up: what happened? He sees a lion furiously attacking Stan with everything its got. A lion in its prime... A real lion. GRROOWWLL!

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: .. JASMINE. ..?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lights CLICK on: Hub and Garth run out, carrying shotguns

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hub, Garth, and Mae run toward the frightful HOWLS: GGGGRRROOO... The cry CHOKES and cuts off, mid-roar there's one last death-rattle WHEEZE... then SILENCE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hub, Garth, and Mae run up, see the lion sprawled atop Stan, both lie still. Walter picks up the lion's head.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Jasmine! Hub checks the lion and Stan. Hub shakes his head sadly. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: Dead.

dialogues.speaker: MAE
dialogues.text: My god! He's dead? Stan's dead?

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: Oh, he'll live, I was talking about the lion. All see Walter's bruises, put two and two together HUB (Cont'd) What happened... did he do that? Hub GROWLS and grabs Stan, but Garth stops him.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: We have to get him to the hospital. Mae, get your car. Mae! Your car! Mae is nearly hysterical, but she nods, rushes off. GARTH (Cont'd) Let's get the lion off him. All turn over the limp lion, look down. Garth WHISTLES. GARTH (Cont'd) I believe this man's gonna need some stitches.

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: A lot of stitches. But Walter only cares about Jasmine: he cradles the limp head of the valiant lion in his lap.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: What happened to her?

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: It looks like her old heart just gave out in all the excitement. She was plenty old, you know.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Look! She's... smiling. They look: she does indeed look as if she's smiling.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: Well! I'd say she died happy. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: She died with her boots on. That's the main thing.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: Yup. Protecting her cub.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: She really was a real lion, wasn't she? There, at the end. A real jungle lion. A real Africa lion! Hub and Garth nod. Beyond them, the cornfield rustles in the pale early morning light. DISSOLVE TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside the cornfield, wearing Sunday best: Walter, Hub, Garth, and the animals surround a grave-mound: they've buried the lion where she belonged, in the cornfield. Walter SNIFFLES as he POUNDS in a wooden cross, says a silent prayer, and looks up at his uncles. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: You finish packing? (Walter nods sadly) Your momma's gonna be back from the hospital soon. You can wait for her on the front porch. He nods. The uncles sadly watch him trudge to the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forlorn, Walter waits on the front porch, surrounded by dogs and the pig, all in the same mournful mood. Mae's Cadillac pulls up, with a bandaged Stan the front- seat passenger. Mae exits, approaches:

dialogues.speaker: MAE
dialogues.text: So, all packed? Where's your suitcase?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Upstairs. In my room.

dialogues.speaker: MAE
dialogues.text: Let's go get it.  WHITE Revision - 8/25/02 87.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stan is a mummy, immobilized in bandages head to toe. His eyes widen in alarm as he sees Hub and Garth approach

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: Howdy, Stan.

dialogues.speaker: STAN
dialogues.text: Mmmm! = Mmmm-MMMM !

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: Stan, you were lucky... lucky that lion got you before we did! Stan's eyes grow very wide. HUB (Cont'd) Know they do to men who hurt kids back in North Africa, Stan? (Stan shakes his head) Well! First they take a rope....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter looks around his tower room for the last time. Outside the window, Mae sees the uncles lecture to Stan with a lot of descriptive hand-and-arm motions.

dialogues.speaker: MAE
dialogues.text: I wonder what your uncles are saying to Stan?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Probably their "What Every Boy Needs to Know About Being A Man" speech.

dialogues.speaker: MAE
dialogues.text: I'm glad to see they're making friends. Walter carefully puts his precious photo of Jasmine atop his clothes, closes his suitcase. MAE (Cont'd) There now. Ready?  WHITE Revision - 8/25/02 88. 141

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: ...and then, after every bone in the body is broken, they take a razor sharp sword and two hundred pounds of salt.... Just getting warmed-up, Hub sees Walter and Mae approach. HUB (Cont'd) Oh well. To make a long story short, Stan: you and me can be friends.... or we can be enemies. Hub gives him that look: the helpless Stan quakes. Hub SLAPS Stan hard on the back: Stan MOANS, nearly faints.

dialogues.speaker: MAE
dialogues.text: I hope Walter wasn't too much trouble.

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: We managed.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: (nods at Stan) What are you gonna do about him?

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: Man like that's got no business being around your boy.

dialogues.speaker: MAE
dialogues.text: Oh, of course! What kind of mother would I be? We're just dropping him off in Vegas on our way.... Time to say goodbye. Garth SIGHS, Hub looks uptight, the dogs look miserable, and Walter's eyes grow wet. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: ...I'll be back for the rest of that speech... if... if... Walter stumbles. But Hub answers definitively:

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: I'll be here. Walter SNIFFLES, then rushes to Hub and hugs him, low. Hub awkwardly pats him on the back. Walter turns to Garth (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Thanks for the stories. And everything! It meant an awful, awful lot.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: I'm glad. They hug tightly. Then Walter climbs into the car

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The animals sadly press their noses against Walter's window. As the car pulls away, he starts to cry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The uncles sadly watch the Cadillac drive away.

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: Damn it! That woman don't deserve that kid! Let's get us a lawyer!

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: No judge is gonna take a child away from its mother and give it to two old bachelor uncles.

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: Maybe she'll sell him to us! How much money we got?

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: Hub! There's nothing we can do. He's gone! Hub glowers. They watch until the car is out of sight.

dialogues.speaker: DAY 144
dialogues.text: Walter looks back, watches the "WARNING" signs pass behin The house and tower gradually fade from view.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Cadillac turns onto the highway, accelerates away.

dialogues.speaker: DAY 146
dialogues.text: All settle in. But something still bothers walter (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHITE Revision - 8/25/02 90. 146 147

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Mom? It was all a lie, wasn't it? About the uncles being bank robbers. And you were in on it the whole time, right?

dialogues.speaker: MAE
dialogues.text: I did what's best for us. You want those men to come after Stan? He looks out, sees the field of bluebonnets pass by.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: So. Where we going?

dialogues.speaker: MAE
dialogues.text: I told you. Las Vegas.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: I mean after. After we drop Stan off.

dialogues.speaker: MAE
dialogues.text: Well now, honey, Stan's gonna need a lot of looking after... She reaches over and pats Stan gently on the knee. And suddenly Walter knows everything: he GASPS. Walter grabs the car door, opens it, sees asphalt and grass racing past... and starts to jump. MAE (Cont'd) Walter! The Caddy SWERVES violently, Mae SLAMS on the brakes Stan SMASHES into the windshield... and Walter jumps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter rolls to a stop, jumps to his feet, scuffed but unhurt. He runs up a small rise overlooking the road. Below, the Caddy backs into frame, BRAKES hard, SLAMMING Stan backward: he YELPS.

dialogues.speaker: MAE
dialogues.text: Walter! She jumps out, runs after him. Walter collapses in the field of bluebonnets, and CRIES. Mae approaches: MAE (Cont'd) Walter! What's got into you?! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHITE Revision - 8/25/02 g1. 147 148

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: You're still marrying him? After... everything?

dialogues.speaker: MAE
dialogues.text: He's not so bad... a little rough around the edges, but he can change.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Mom!

dialogues.speaker: MAE
dialogues.text: He says he loves me and I'm not getting any younger....

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Has he hit you yet?

dialogues.speaker: MAE
dialogues.text: Mind your own business! Walter stares at her knowingly. She looks away.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: You always think a new boyfriend solves everything. But you always pick losers. And he's the worst of 'em all.

dialogues.speaker: MAE
dialogues.text: Walter. We got no choice.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Maybe you don't....

dialogues.speaker: MAE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Mom. Do something for me. For once. Do something that's best for me. OK? Promise?

dialogues.speaker: MAE
dialogues.text: Well... Let's hear it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stan lays askew, face SMUSHED into the windshield; he GROANS. He strains to look, sees Walter and Mae talking. Then, both hug, crying. He wonders: what the hell?  WHITE Revision - 8/25/02 92. 149 150

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hub, Garth, and the animals listlessly sit on the porch in their "waiting for salesmen" places. Long pause.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: Salesmen oughta be along in two, three hours.

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: Whoop de do. A dog's head goes up; so does another's. The uncles look up: far down the road, a small figure approaches, on foot The uncles squint: who is it? The dogs run down the road BARKING. Finally the uncles' eyes bug out: they drop their shotguns and hustle down the steps to meet...

dialogues.speaker: WALTER 150
dialogues.text: Walter, carrying his bag, trudges up to the uncles, sets down his bag, and smiles. All three--this new family-- grin at each other. Happily, this time.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: If I'm gonna live here, there's some conditions....

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: One: you both stick around until I'm through high school at least, preferably college. You both got responsibilities now: PTA, Boy Scouts, Little League, the works. Hub GROANS. Garth hides a smile. Finally, both nod.

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: Looks like we got no choice...!

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Two: you both take better care of yourselves: more vegetables, less meat. Hub throws up his hands, storms for the house. Walter and Garth follow.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: I wonder if traveling salesmen sell school supplies...? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Three: no dangerous stuff. No fighting teenagers, no airplanes...

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: Now wait one minute!

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: ...at least until I'm out of college. Maybe longer...

dialogues.speaker: HUB
dialogues.text: What do the hell you expect us to die of? Old age...? Walter smiles, nods: exactly. Garth smiles at Walter.

dialogues.speaker: GARTH
dialogues.text: So Walt. Welcome home. And Walter breaks into the biggest, sunniest smile of his entire life. So far. FADE TO BLACK. TITLE: "Thirty years later..."

dialogues.speaker: YA-HOOOO
dialogues.text: Wearing goggles and helmets, two old men SCREAM like craz kids as their SPUTTERING biplane loops and rolls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The plane flies away, barely under control: it careens and SPUTTERS off into a huge heroic sunset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man draws at a table: he's forty, handsome, athletic, confident. He smiles a familiar smile, a smile full of grace. He's the ADULT WALT. The phone RINGS.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Hello? Behind him are awards and drawings on a wall: a successfu syndicated comic strip in the style of Calvin & Hobbes. The romantic Arabic theme PLAYS. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TELEPHONE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Walter Caldwell...? I have bad news. It's about your two uncles. Sir, they've passed away. A sketch: a child's lettered sign "Africa" points to a cornfield where a whimsical lion sticks out her head. The lion and her companion, a small boy in a pith helmet explore an exotic African jungle cornfield. The strip is entitled: "Walter and Jasmine". TELEPHONE (Cont'd) It's a blessing they didn't suffer. Night: by a cornfield and lake is a familiar ramshackle house, a light on at the top of its leaning tower TELEPHONE (Cont'd) And a blessing too, in a way, that they went together... A hand freezes over a drawing: the boy addresses his "troops" that include a pack of dogs, chickens, and a surly pig. The lion looks skeptical. TELEPHONE (Cont'd) I found their will. I'll give it to you when you get here. Walt's face: the news he's dreaded has finally come.

dialogues.speaker: DAY 154
dialogues.text: Walt drives, turns in, passes the familiar "Warning!" - signs, faded now. Ahead, the farmhouse looms, its tower leans even more. He parks beside a SHERIFF's car

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF
dialogues.text: Walter Caldwell?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: walt. Walt and the Sheriff shake hands, then both turn to look at the barn: in an upper opening, the tail of the crashed biplane sticks out, upside down at a crazy angle. Walt stifles a LAUGH. The Sheriff scratches his head. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHITE Revision - 8/25/02 95.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF
dialogues.text: Best I can figure, they were trying to fly through the barn upside down. Walt shakes his head, a LAUGH bursts out, is cut off.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: I always knew that airplane would get them.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF
dialogues.text: We had a bunch of reporters out here earlier. Even CNN. I guess anytime a biplane from the first World War crashes, doing acrobatics, flown by two ninety year-old men with no pilots' licenses, well.... Both try to keep straight faces, finally both grin. SHERIFF (Cont'd) Here. I found their will. A single piece of paper. Walt reads the scrawls:

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: "The kid gets it all. Just plant us in the damn garden with the stupid lion." Walt's eyes become wet. He looks out at the garden, and the lake beyond. Wind rustles stalks of corn. WALT (Cont'd) These last few months, my Uncle Hub's been sick with pneumonia. From sleepwalking. More and more lately, we'd find him out there in the middle of the night, staring out over the water.... The Sheriff looks at the plane with new understanding.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF
dialogues.text: Well. They had a good long run both of them. And they went out with their boots on. Walt nods: they sure did that.  WHITE Revision - 8/25/02 96. 156 157 158

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The day of the funeral, in the garden: it's a real garden now, with a variety of huge, beautiful vegetables. MOURNERS, mostly curious locals, gingerly make their way through rows of beautiful vegetables to the grave site, between the tomatoes and the watermelons.

dialogues.speaker: THE CARS 157
dialogues.text: WALT'S WIFE arrives. TWO BOYS bounce out of the car, dueling with curved plastic Arab swords.

dialogues.speaker: WALT'S WIFE
dialogues.text: Put the swords back in the car The boys turn: one wears an eye-patch and has a crayon- drawn face scar.

dialogues.speaker: BOYS
dialogues.text: Oh, mom...!

dialogues.speaker: WALT'S WIFE
dialogues.text: Go stand with your father

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys run up to Walt.

dialogues.speaker: BOYS
dialogues.text: Dad! Dad!

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Hub, you're standing on the squash. Garth, lose the eyepatch. Walt sees four prosperous-looking MEN in their fifties arrive with their wives; the four eye him, grinning.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Walter? Little Walter...?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, I don't remember.... The four turn up collars on the suit jackets: the hoods. WALT (Cont'd) Frankie and the hoods! I didn't recognize you guys without your leather jackets! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHITE Revision - 8/25/02 97.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: By now, perhaps two dozen people stand among the vegetables. All wait, look at Walt expectantly. WALT (Cont'd) Oh. Well.... In her life, my mother made a lot of mistakes. But once, by sheer accident, she did do something right: she dumped me off one summer with two crazy old men. And there, in the most unlikely of places, I found a home. My home. The wind blows softly, rustles the corn stalks. WALT (Cont'd) They had no idea of how to deal with a troubled little kid. So, they told me stories. Amazing, unbelievable stories. Stories about harems, sheiks and princesses, valiant men and evil villains. About courage. Honor. They knew those stories were exactly what a terrified young boy needed to hear. Walt smiles wryly, shakes his head. WALT (Cont'd) Even though we cynical adults know such tall tales can't possibly be true, I believed them. In a way, I still believe them. Because, as my Uncle Hub taught me, just because something isn't true, that's no reason you shouldn't believe in it. That's what fathers do for sons: teach them the things that, despite everything, are worth believing in. Some folks don't understand. But others do. WALT (Cont'd) It was the proudest day of my life when I turned eighteen and Hub gave me his full, unabridged, "What Every Boy Needs to Know About Being a Man" speech. TITTERS, smiles. Frankie and the hoods nod knowingly. WALT (Cont'd) And one of these days, I'll give that same speech to my sons. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BLUE Revision - 11/3/02 98. 158

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The two look up at their dad and grin. WALT (Cont'd) I really, really loved those two old characters. I'm really going to miss them.... He wipes his eyes, looks up. WALT (Cont'd) Please, as you leave, help yourself to all the vegetables you can carry. LAUGHS. And it's over. All start to leave. But then: WHOOSH! Airbrakes: two huge livestock trucks pull in. Everyone looks puzzled. Big doors SLAM DOWN: SOLDIERS on horseback leap out, riding beautiful Arabian stallions. Foreign soldiers wearing kepis and kerchiefs, desert uniforms. Foreign Legion uniforms.

dialogues.speaker: WALT'S BOYS
dialogues.text: It's The Legion! The Legion forms up into a mounted Honor Guard. walt can't believe his eyes. Nor can anyone. Then, they see another vehicle drive up: a long, long limo pulls up and parks; its doors open: a dozen ARAB WOMEN wearing veils emerge in a dense pack, surrounding someone of obvious importance. The pack approaches. Walt's boys' eyes shine. They watch the Legion on horseback, stallions prancing in glorious precision. And then, at the garden's edge, the pack of women parts: revealing an old, old man in a wheelchair, an ancient SHEIK who wears an eyepatch and has a long scar running down one side of his once-handsome but cruel face. WALT'S BOYS (Cont'd) Yikes! Walt is startled; his sons jump behind him, and peer out: The old sheik glares at the coffins with incredible fury. The women start WAILING mournfully; the old sheik glares at them, then shakes his fist at the two coffins. Old enemies die hard. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PINK Revision - 11/3/02 99.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The amazed locals watch as the mounted Honor Guard snaps to attention. With a stunned realization, the adult Walt is now certain of what young Walter finally, truly believed:

dialogues.speaker: BOYS
dialogues.text: It was all true. Huh Dad?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Yes. It was all true. And so it was. ROMANTIC ARAB THEME UP FULL.
